WT01-B10-89IA054-000903-B001-116http://ivf.com:80/coping.html 206.185.60.251 19970123215640 text/html 5123HTTP/1.0 200 OKDate: Thu, 23 Jan 1997 21:58:20 GMTServer: Apache/1.1.1Content-type: text/htmlContent-length: 4952Last-modified: Tue, 14 Feb 1995 03:22:01 GMT Stress Management Stress Management COPING STRATEGIES FOR THE 1990'S Part of the problem with this idea of "coping" with infertility is that we all have the notion that we should be able to do it gracefully, with a minimum of tears and hysterics. WHO TOLD US THAT WAS COPING? Who made the rules that said don't cry "too" much, don't show your feelings "too" much, don't let your feelings affect your work and relationships at all? The next important question is, why have we bought it? What is wrong with having our feelings? Grief is a natural process and infertility is an experience we have to grieve on a chronic basis. It is an on-going crisis which provides us with tremendous stress. In short, it's a terrible experience we wouldn't wish on our worst enemies (most of the time, that is). So who says we should look like the cast of Dallas or Dynasty as we suffer? People can't go through infertility without being affected emotionally unless their feelings are being so well protected that they're not in touch with them. Men and women deal with their feelings differently. If we, women, try to repress our feelings, they get bigger and bigger, more and more ominous, until we feel we are out of control and our emotions have become a monstrous ogre about to eat us up. Men might actually feel more threatened expressing themselves since they've usually been trained to repress their emotions. There's no right or wrong and there are ways men and women can help each other learn to balance thinking and feeling as they struggle side by side on their journey toward parenthood. Learn now you're normal. So don't put yourself down for how you've chosen to cope. Find the positives about your style. Focus on how well you're doing and give yourself lots of strokes for how well you've succeeded. For instance, many women put themselves down for feeling the need to talk to people a lot. Well, using support systems is one of the top ways recommended to folks going through stress full life experiences. Aren't you clever! If people don't want to be there for you they will find a way to create distance, and if they don't have a clue about how to help you, it doesn't mean you're a hopeless case. Most people don't know how to deal with such intense pain. So give yourself positive self talk about how good you are at reaching out for help. If you can't find the positives in what you are doing ask a friend, your partner. There's always a way! Infertility often creates or exacerbates marital conflict. Find time to talk about it and decide if it's old problems or created by your infertility experience. Talk about the ways you've solved problems before and see if any of these work. If not, ask friends what they've done or seek out counseling. It is normal for marriages to have problems during this time. Friends and family members often seem insensitive and say or do things out of their ignorance, discomfort, or feelings of helplessness. Educate them when you are strong enough. Tell them how you feel. Don't wait until you are in crisis or you'll tend to talk yourself out of dealing with them and they'll never learn what you need from them. Medical caregivers have feelings about your infertility too and may react in a number of ways which may or may not feel good to you. Give them feedback about what feels good and what doesn't so they learn, and so your anger and resentment don't build. You'll be helping yourself right now and contributing to other infertile couples in the future. Co-workers and employers may react also in hurtful ways or not understand your need for time off, your emotional ups and downs. Educate them where you can. Find supports in your workplace. Imagine you have some other illness that doesn't have the social stigma of infertility and give yourself as much permission as you would in that situation to use your time as medically recommended, and expect others to honor this as well. Remember what you've done in the past to make it through difficult times and see if it can work for you now as well: find time to have fun, read books, do nice things for yourself, buy things, meet new people, take exciting classes, learn to do something you've always been afraid to try, develop a sense of humor about the infertility experience (this actually can be done on your better days), use this time to develop deeper and more intimate relationships with your partner and others you care for, go for counseling, join a support group at RESOLVE, or do anything else your heart desires. You deserve it! ARHC Homepage This HTML code is Copyright (C) 1995 by Mark Perloe, M.D., P.C. Atlanta, GA, USA. WT01-B10-90IA054-000903-B001-139http://ivf.com:80/listen.html 206.185.60.251 19970123215652 text/html 2766HTTP/1.0 200 OKDate: Thu, 23 Jan 1997 21:58:29 GMTServer: Apache/1.1.1Content-type: text/htmlContent-length: 2595Last-modified: Mon, 26 Aug 1996 00:48:56 GMT On Listening ON LISTENING by Ralph Roughton, Older Friends Group Hartford, Conn. April 1981 When I ask you to listen to me and you start by giving advice, you have not done what I asked. When I ask you to listen to me and you begin to tell me why I shouldn't feel that way, you are trampling on my feelings. When I ask you to listen to me and you feel you have to do something to solve my problem, you have failed me, strange as it rna seem. Listen! All I ask is that you listen, not talk or do... just hear me. When you do something for me that I can and need to do for myself, you contribute to my fear and inadequacy And I can do for myself. I'm not helpless Maybe discouraged and faltering, but not helpless. But when you accept as simple fact that I do feel what I feel, no matter how irrational, then I can quit trying to convince you and get about the business of understanding what's behind this irrational feeling. And when that's clear, the answers are obvious and I don't need advice. Irrational feelings make sense when we understand what's behind them. Perhaps that's why prayer works, sometimes, for some people... because God is mute, and He or She doesn't give advice or try to fix things. God just listens and lets you work it out for yourself. So, please listen and just hear me. And it you want to talk, wait a minute for your turn, and I'll listen to you. WT01-B10-96IA054-000903-B003-296http://ivf.com:80/npt.html 206.185.60.251 19970123220259 text/html 3439HTTP/1.0 200 OKDate: Thu, 23 Jan 1997 22:04:41 GMTServer: Apache/1.1.1Content-type: text/htmlContent-length: 3268Last-modified: Sun, 24 Mar 1996 22:31:45 GMT The Modified U-TECHNIQUE NORPLANT REMOVAL "U"-Technique Norplant Removal The U-technique for Norplant removal is a simple procedure that was initially developed by an Indonesian physician, Dr. Untung Praptohardjo, to assist in the difficult Norplant removal. Modification has improved its effectiveness. Its advantages include ease of performance, small incision size, and minimal dissection. This technique requires the use of a special clamp that is a modified version of the no-scalpel vasectomy clamp. Although similar in appearance to the no-scalpel vasectomy clamp, the modified clamp has different dimensions thereby minimizing the risk of tearing the implant. Download Norplant Video 2.5meg avi STEPS: Both ends of each implant are marked with a pen and the implant is drawn on the arm to facilitate its removal. The arm is prepped with Betadine solution. A site approximately one-third from the base of the fan between the third and fourth implants is injected with Xylocaine 1% with bicarb 1cc/10cc. The injection is then carried laterally underneath the implant with a total of 4-6 cc of local anesthetic injected under the three implants on each side. A 4mm incision is made with a #11 blade. The Norplant removal clamp is inserted so as to grasp each implant approximately one-third of the way from the bottom end. This is made easier by stabilizing each implant with a finger from the opposite hand. Using gentle traction, each implant is brought to the incision where using gauze sponge, #22 needless or knife blade, the capsule is gently incised. If a knife is used the capsule is scraped gentle in a direction parallel to the implant and not in a cutting motion across the implant as this may transect the implant and make removal more difficult. The implants are removed. After removing all implants, the implants are displayed for the patient to see and then dressing is placed over the incision site. Postoperative wound care is similar to other Norplant removal techniques. As levonorgestrel is cleared within 96 hours, alternative contraception should be provided prior to discharging the patient. For more information, please read Modified U-Technique, Reynolds R: Journal of FamilyPractice (Feb 1995, Vol 40, pages 173-80) The "U" technique Norplant removal clamp can be ordered for $125 includes shipping. Please include $7.50 sales tax. Checks can be mailed to Atlanta Reproductive Health Centre, 285 Boulevard, N.E., Suite 320, Atlanta, GA 30312. Phone orders can be taken at +1 404-265-3662, or FAX your request to +1 404-265-4276. Please include VISA, MC or Discover for FAX orders. WT01-B10-98IA054-000903-B004-45http://ivf.com:80/inciid.html 206.185.60.251 19970123220344 text/html 10295HTTP/1.0 200 OKDate: Thu, 23 Jan 1997 22:05:21 GMTServer: Apache/1.1.1Content-type: text/htmlContent-length: 10123Last-modified: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 00:19:06 GMT INCIID InterNational Council on Infertility Information Dissemination The International Council on Infertility Information Dissemination (INCIID) (pronounced "inside") is a new, nonprofit organization dedicated to promoting the exchange expanding the reach of such on-line networks to a wider range of infertile consumers, while simultaneously improving the quality and immediacy of available information. INCIID also conducts a comprehensive, ongoing media campaign to educate the general public and garner a greater understanding about the emotional, financial and informational struggle facing sufferers of infertility. ADVISORY BOARD INCIID has brought together a group of internationally renowned infertility experts to serve on its Advisory Board and take an active role in conferences, cyberspace events, educational video development and media events. To date, advisory board members include Dr. Alan Beer, director of reproductive medicine at the Robert R. McCormick Clinics at the University of Health Sciences Chicago Medical School, Dr. Carolyn Coulam, director of reproductive immunology at Genetics and IVF Institute in Fairfax, Va.; Dr. Marc Goldstein, director of the Male Reproduction and Microsurgery Unit at the New York Hospital, Cornell Medical Center and co-author of "The Couple's Guide to Infertility"; Dr. Niels H. Lauersen, medical director of The New York Medical Service for Reproductive Medicine and author of "Getting Pregnant: What Couples Need to Know Right Now" and six other books on women's health; Dr. Mark Perloe, director of reproductive endocrinology, infertility and in-vitro fertilization at Georgia Baptist Medical Center, and Peggy Robin, author of "How to be a Successful Fertility Patient: Your Guide to Getting the Best Possible Medical Help to Have a Baby. " NATIONAL CONFERENCE INCIID is hosting an annual conference featuring workshops and seminars with nationally acknowledged fertility experts and panel participants. The first conference is tentatively set for Spring, 1996. Workshop topics include "On the Horizon---New Treatments," "Demystifying High Tech Treatments (IVF, GIFT, ZIFT), " "ICSI and other Male Factor Treatments," "Examining the Legal Aspects of Donor Procedures and Adoption," and "Diagnosis and Treatment of Immune Problems." A "Conference Summary and Report" will be published following the conference and will be available to the general public. EDUCATIONAL VIDEOS INCIID is developing a series of informational videos about a range of infertility diagnoses and specific treatment options. The INCIID video series will be available at a reasonable price for the general consumer. NATIONAL INFERTILITY SURVEY During 1995, INCIID will conduct the first-ever, on-line infertility survey designed to measure the degree of infertility and pregnancy loss among the general population. Using Prodigy's on-line survey capabilities and the expertise of professional pollsters, the INCIID-Prodigy Infertility Survey will reach nearly 2 million Prodigy users. The results of the survey will be released in 1996. CYBERSPACE In addition to being an international presence in a variety of on-line networks such as Prodigy, America Online and the INCIID is also developing its own "Homepage" for the Internet's "World Wide Web." This easily accessed Internet site will be a permanent location for information and updates on the latest infertility research and treatment programs. INTERNATIONAL, NATIONAL, LOCAL MEDIA Experts believe that as many as one in six couples experience some degree of infertility, yet there continues to be a shroud of mystery around the medical problems which prevent couples from having children. Those uneducated about the causes of infertility and pregnancy loss may never learn that there are often simple and inexpensive steps which can help them attain their dreams of having families. Frustrated with medical practitioners who are unfamiliar with new treatments and technologies, the infertile often don't know where to begin seeking a diagnosis and solution. The founders of INCIID have extensive public relations backgrounds and will enlist the media in ending the silence and misinformation about infertility and pregnancy loss. Using the expertise of its Advisory Board and statistics and research from professional organizations such as the American Fertility Society and the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, INCIID will involve international, national and local news media in its education efforts. NEWSLETTER INCIID members receive a quarterly newsletter which provides resource referrals, a "Question and Answer" column written by a panel of experts, articles about new technologies and treatment modalities and information about upcoming INCIID events. MEMBERSHIP INCIID offers three levels of annual Membership: General Members: $25 includes quarterly newsletter subscription and 10 percent conference registration discount. Couples may join under a "General" membership. Founding Members: $50 includes quarterly newsletter subscription, 15 percent conference registration discount, and complimentary Conference Summary and Report. Professional Members: $100 includes quarterly newsletter subscription, complimentary Conference Summary and Report, 15 percent conference registration discount for staff and 10 percent conference registration discount for referred patients. Ms. Davey's interest in infertility and pregnancy loss came as a direct result of her personal experience with four pregnancy losses in four years. Larisa Kochorva and Anne Atkinson had a dream that Russian women would have access to the same quality of women�s healthcare as American women. They shared that vision with Dr.Perloe, director of reproductive endocrinology and infertility at Georgia Baptist Medical Center, during a Norplant conference in July of 1992 in St. Petersburg, Russia. Perloe met with Russians specialists in gynecology, urology and general surgery in an effort to assess their needs, desires and capabilities. Dr. Michael Herndon, director of comparative medicineat Georgia Baptist Medical Center, joined the team to help plan a multiyear strategy. Initially, our efforts would focus on the introduction of the latest endoscopic surgical techniques. To meet our goals required an assessment of their healthcare infrastructure and resources, as well as a comprehensive medical education program and supply effort. The American and Russian partners jointly developed a program that included lectures, laboratory sessions as well as surgical training. One of our goals was to introduce these new surgical concepts to the largest possible audience. Intensive training would be reserved for a smaller group. By limiting the endoscopic training to a smaller group, we were able to insure that the Russian physicians could safely continue developing their skills after the two week program was completed. The first symposium involved eleven American participants and 250 Russian participants. $200,000 of equipment and supplies were provided. During the two week exchange, separate lecture programs were held in gynecology, urology and general surgery. Laboratory training sessions covered equipment operation, endoscopic suturing, hysteroscopy, cholecystectomy, hernia repair and pelvic lymph node dissection. Russian physicians performed twenty-two operations with their American partners. Meetings were held late into St. Petersburg�s �White Nights� to plan the June 94 symposium which would provide greater focus on women�s healthcare. Expanded sessions were planned to address menopause, hysterosocpy, endoscopy, endometriosis, ultrasonography, contraception, highrisk obstetrics and perioperative nursing issues. The Second International Women�s Health and Endoscopy Symposium took over a year to coordinate. This was greatly facilitated by the signing of the A.I.H.A. partnership agreement between Georgia Baptist Medical Center and First Medical Institute-Pavlov as well as the personal support of David Harrell, CEO of Georgia Baptist Medical Center. Our partnership enabled Russian specialists to actively participate in the planning and implementation of our project. Our second symposium involved 17 American participants, hundreds of Russian participants, and over $250,000 of donated supplies, time and shipping costs. Although the general format for this years� symposium was similar to last year, lectures, laboratories and surgical procedures, there were some notable differences. This years� symposium included case presentations by Russian physicians as well as lectures highlighting specific areas of expertise. These presentations pointed out many differing beliefs and resulted in a lively exchange of views. In America, the current therapy for endometriosis relies on surgery and hormonal manipulation. American gynecologists are just now beginning to explore the immunologic basis for this disease. Our Russian colleagues have vast experience using immunotherapy for endometriosis and frequently rely on immunotherapy as first line treatment. Management of the menopause is another area where differences were noted. Many Russian physicians expressed the belief that the debility associated with estrogen deprivation, menopause, is natural and should be endured, not treated. When a woman�s symptoms are severe enough, galvanic treatments and antipsychotic drugs may be employed. Other Russian physicians share the view of their American counterparts that while estrogen deprivation is part of the natural aging process, its sequalae are not. These women should be treated with estrogen replacement therapy. A major goal of this years� effort was to provide slides and handouts in Russian. Our contraceptive slide presentations were entirely in Russian and an extensive Russian handout was made available. On the topic of contraceptive beliefs, our views also differed widely. Despite the fact that birth control pills are held to be safe and effective by American physicians, Russian physicians are leery of hormonal contraception. It is noteworthy that while one Russian physician presented exciting research that has led to improved hormonal contraceptive options, many Russian physicians and the population at large ignore this contraceptive option. In order to better understand the status of women�s healthcare in Russia, we held focus groups and discussed issues in family planning and menopause. A session was held with Russian women physicians to assess their views. The nursing program was especially well received. Issues of patient care, sterilization, centralization of OR facilities and resources was addressed. The Russian nurses were enthusiastic about the potential development of an expanded role and looked forward to future efforts to revise and expand the Russian nursing curricula. Throughout the symposium, discussions were held with the university president, Nikolai Yaitsky and Larisa Kochorova, director of Delor, on how to improve efficiency and thereby achieve the maximum utilization of resources. As a direct result of these discussions, a new position has been created at the university to coordinate endoscopy equipment, training and supplies. The university has committed to develop a centralized endosurgery facility thereby enabling all physicians access to this technology. Over the past few years, we have worked closely developing relationships with our colleagues. We stayed with their families, communicated openly and immersed ourselves in the Russian culture. We strongly believe that our successes would not have been possible without the level of trust which has developed over the past three years. Our personal goals are: to hold a third symposium on endoscopy and women�s health; to provide further assistance in the centralization of endoscopy services; to foster an ongoing exchange of physicians, nurses and information; and to establish an economically sustainable women�s health clinic. We look forward to sharing our experience and resources with other A.I.H.A. programs with similar interests. WT01-B10-101IA054-000903-B006-145http://ivf.com:80/Beat.html 206.185.60.251 19970123221128 text/html 10265HTTP/1.0 200 OKDate: Thu, 23 Jan 1997 22:13:07 GMTServer: Apache/1.1.1Content-type: text/htmlContent-length: 10093Last-modified: Wed, 04 Jan 1995 23:23:04 GMT Beat to Beat Article 1st Symposium FIRST INTERNATIONAL ENDOSCOPY SYMPOSIUM St. Petersburg, Russia May 1993 by Dr. Michael HerndonThrough a collaborative effort involving several specialties, a multi-disciplinary team from Georgia Baptist Medical Center Co-Directed by Dr. Mark Perloe, Dr. Michael Herndon and Anne Atkinson offered a course in ENDOSCOPY with the First St. Petersburg Medical Institute-Pavlov in the city founded by Peter the Great in 1704: St. Petersburg, Russia. This course ran from May 10-17, 1993, during the early part of the "White Nights" when the sun rises at 3 a.m. and sets at 11:30 p.m. It was the first in what is planned to be an on going affiliation with the ST. Petersburg Medical Institute. The preparation began many months ago as Drs. Perloe, Herndon and Anne Atkinson began to work out the logistics of having an endoscopy course in a country which did not speak English, has an 8 hour time differential and was located over 5,000 miles away. No detail could be taken for granted. All the equipment, supplies and lecture materials needed for the course had to be anticipated and shipped to Russia. None of the course directors had initially realized the amount of work it would require to take this idea of an truly international endoscopic training symposium from conception through reality. But, to their credit, they stuck with it and the course was a complete success. According to Dr. Herndon without the help of such people as Dr. Perloe's office staff, the staff of medical education, Alton Westberry and his department the work would not have been completed on time. In addition the Vendor support was wonderful! Ralf Sander of CIRCON/ACMI provided video and Laparoscopic equipment as well as technical support. Christian Erbe of ERBE Electronics provided a wealth of information and the electrosurgical generators. Between these two companies 6 huge wooden crates measuring 4x4x6 FEET were shipped to Russia. Ralf and Christian brought with them not only equipment but technical expertise that was indispensable. The enthusiasm and sheer hard work Ralf Sander of Germany, Christian Erbe of Belgium and Patrick Laughlin of Atlanta exhibited was an inspiration to all. Drs. Perloe and Herndon were heard to say on many occasions, "without these individuals, this course could not have succeeded as well as it did". In addition, United States Surgical Company donated disposable surgical instrumentation and Baxter much needed supplies. To all of these vendors, and many more, (Valley Lab, Organon, Carl Storz and Apple Medical to name a few)...our heart felt THANK YOU! The group from Georgia Baptist Medical Center was as listed by specialty - Gynecology: Drs. Mark Perloe, Steve Saltzman and Rhonda Latif. General Surgery: Drs. Titus Duncan and Steve Eubanks. Urology: Dr. Thomas Schoborg. Comparative Medicine: Dr. Michael Herndon. Nursing: Nadra Cohran, and Research: Dr. Carole Ehleben. Translation, the key to success or failure, fell to Anne Atkinson whose fluent Russian made communication a joy. This distinguished group was assembled not only for their expertise, which is considerable, but also because of their belief in the value of an International Endoscopy Symposium. So dedicated was this group that many of its members had to pay their own way and use vacation time for the opportunity to teach. Each of the members of the group lived with a sponsoring Russian family while in St. Petersburg. These families were warm and caring. The group from Georgia Baptist has many wonderful stories to tell and I encourage the interested reader to corner one of the participants and simply ask them about their experience. Then stand back as they talk your ear off about all the unique and varied cultural and personal impressions each brought home. The Symposium was divided into three sections: lectures, laboratory and operative. Over 300 physicians participated in at least one of these sections. The main lecture hall at the Institute reminded one of pictures of 150 doctors and students standing around an auditorium listening to one of the senior professors demonstrating the latest in medical theory and technique. It was here that the course began. After being made completely welcome by the faculty, Dr. Perloe gave his introductory remarks. The lectures that morning by Drs. Perloe, Eubanks and Herndon showed once again the importance and difficulties of a language barrier. But through the efforts of all involved the day went smoothly. At the outset the course directors were concerned as to whether the interest in lectures would remain. We all realize how interest can fade on a beautiful spring afternoon. This was not to be the case, however, all the lectures were standing room only. Faculty and students alike could be found in the hall waiting to take an empty chair. Specialty lectures which were intended to be limited to 18 hand picked leading Russian physicians had to be increased to 50 due to repeated requests. Their "experimental lab" was a picturesque building with a semicircular stone entrance. Once inside the building you could not escape the feeling of time standing still. These rooms had seen thousands of wide eyed youths (in Russia students begin a six year medical school curriculum directly out of high school) learn the fundamentals of anatomy, pathology and general surgery as they moved through their training. It was here that 6 working stations were assembled allowing the plan for 18 participants to learn the details of the surgeries they hoped to perform. Once again the instructors had to rise to the occasion of literally hundreds of medical students parading through in an effort to actually witness a technology that none of them had ever seen and few knew about in any detail. An unexpectedly large turnout of Surgeons from the St. Petersburg Medical Institute, as well as several from surrounding hospitals, caused the huge lab facility to swell with activity. During this section the details of Endometrial Ablation, Hysteroscopy, resection of Leiomyomas and general Laparoscopy were taught by Drs. Perloe, Saltzman and Latif. Drs. Duncan and Eubanks gave detailed instructions on principals and practices of general laparoscopy as well as how to avoid potential complications. For Dr. Schoborg the challenges were just beginning. After spending considerable time with a team of highly qualified and extremely motivated Urologists on the details of Laparoscopy and Pelvic Lymphadenectomy he then accompanied them to their facility. Upon arrival he discovered a very modern Lithotriptor for breaking up kidney and ureteral stones using the latest in shock wave technology. He was also about to discover they had saved for him a huge, rock hard stone lodged tightly in a patients ureter. Another area in which actively persued was nursing education. Under the experienced hand of Nadra Cochran R.N., a team of Russian nurses who had expressed an interest in Laparoscopy were taught how to prepare for and manage all the varied equipment and instrumentation necessary for safe Endoscopic surgery. Carole Ehleben was able to successfully initiate efforts to bring controlled clinical trials to Pavlov so that the Institute might benefit from the revenues and advanced technology which accompany such studies. Imagine moving all the equipment needed for an operating room across a campus over roads which have so many potholes that a cart cannot roll. Imagine having to move each piece of equipment by hand. Now multiply that by 6 operating rooms and you have some idea of the work that had to be done. In the space of one evening all the necessary equipment required to safely perform multiple laparoscopic techniques had to be mobilized and moved into the operating theater. No amount of thanks can repay Dr. Herndon, Ralf Sander, Christian Erbe and Patrick Laughlin for their efforts. But move they did and all was ready for some of the first Laparoscopic Surgeries and the FIRST Laparoscopic Herniorrhaphy in St. Petersburg's history (Drs Duncan and Eubanks). As is the medical standard in the United States, the physicians first watched Drs. Perloe, Duncan, Saltzman, Eubanks, Schoborg and Latif operate. Next they assisted under the watchful eye of our surgeons. Surgeries included: Laparoscopically Assisted Vaginal Hysterectomy, Endoscopic Evaluation of the Uterus, Laparoscopic evaluation of causes of infertility, Laparoscopic removal of a Gall Bladder, Laparoscopic repair of an Inguinal Hernia and the Endoscopic examination of Ureteral obstruction due to a ureteral stone. Finally, they performed one of the first Laparoscopic Cholecystectomies completely on their own. All the patients recovered quickly and without complication. The symposium received much media attention in St. Petersburg. A description of the course was included in 3 newspaper articles, several radio news reports, a live radio program and 2 television reports. Looking back at the experiences of the group, it is not possible to evaluate all that was learned on both sides. The Russians treated us like family. They were gracious to a fault. We found them to be extremely knowledgeable, merely lacking the access to the technologies we take for granted. We had hoped to find colleagues, what we found were friends. To all of those who participated in the first International Endoscopic Training Symposium the Georgia Baptist Medical Centers welcomes you back and ...CONGRATULATIONS ON A JOB WELL DONE!!! WT01-B10-102IA054-000903-B006-161http://ivf.com:80/focus.html 206.185.60.251 19970123221137 text/html 8729HTTP/1.0 200 OKDate: Thu, 23 Jan 1997 22:13:18 GMTServer: Apache/1.1.1Content-type: text/htmlContent-length: 8558Last-modified: Sun, 12 Jan 1997 19:50:01 GMT  Russian Women's Health Care Symposium: Focus Groups Russian Women's Health Care Symposium Psychological Focus Group Reports Lesley A. Ward, Ph.D.; Caroline Dott, M.s.W., MA;. Marina Egorova, Ph.D. Russian Psychologist Family Planning Focus Group There were 10 Russian women participants and two Russian facilitators and two American leaders. The participants average age was 23. There were two women who had one child each, and the others had no children. The forty questions were basically concerned with availability of knowledge and resources for family planning. The women who had not had children wanted at least two children each, but this was in direct contrast to the women with one child, who were very reluctant to consider having another. The realities of work and family life had taken its toll. There was no systematic, reliable information source for family planning. This phenomena was across the board the continual, central crisis for the fertile Russian female. The rhythm method remains the method of "choice" (a euphemism since they feel there is so little choice). The pill has a negative history with heavy doses bringing many side effects, and relayed messages of negative perceptions being widespread. IUD's are being used now only by the women who have had one child. They are not too expensive and readily available in the drugstores; this usage helps to explain the "one child" syndrome that is now the norm (current Russian statistics show a negative birth rate). The women feel that the medical profession is also lacking in the information and lacking access to family planning resources. The District Medical Centers are particularly noninformative and even hostile to women's questions about gynocological care and contraception. The women report that the women doctors are actually the worst with their responsiveness to the female questions. (This probably is a defensive response because the doctors themselves are uninformed or uneducated in these matters). They prefer male doctors who seem to have more empathy and helpful caringness. These women find there is little knowledge about STDS's and AIDS. Another critical, central issue is that these women report they only visit a doctor when there is a problem. Prevention is not a known concept. The women actually hate going to a doctor. The wait is long and the attitude usually intolerable. Only recently with the avrailability of private doctors do the women feel that their health is receiving proper attention and they can trust the doctor. The sense of choice, which is entirely new in this country, is allowing them some freedom to ask more questions and pursue more avenues of alternative care. But the major obstacles of education and resources in this area as well as the overriding taboo (seen as weird or weak) against Russian women going to a doctor for their female problems loom continuously in the face of women's health care. Menopause/Midlife This group had 7 Russian participants. The average age was 36 and only two of the women did not have children. The focus of the group was to discuss their knowledge of menopause: its effects and treatrnent. The women reported that their knowledge was all second hand from their mothers experiences. Most of them reported that their mothers had had a difficult time. But they did not seek help until in extreme dire strates. There is no knowledge available nor is this problem discussed with the Russian doctors. They were unaware of any treatment for menopause; and they feel this is something one has to sove for herself. They prefer not to think about it until it happens. Then if problems develop, possibly see a doctor or psychologist. But once again, the doctors at the district medical centers are uncomfortable and not helpful with these issues. This is not considered a serious problem and the female is looked at strangely if she asks for family planning care. This is even worse in the smaller cities and towns. Now some help of this kind might be available to the women who have money who can go to private doctors. Only a few said they would discuss it with their husbands, because most men do not want to hear about female problems. Also, employers are agitated if women complain about feminine problems, so they only talk with other women co-workers about the problems. One should not miss work or do less on the job if having side effects. There was a general feeling that women can overcome on their own. They have not trusted the system. Many report the incompetence of their doctors, who are not held personally responsible. They told stories of wrong diagnosis across the board. The issue of money is paramount, because the medical centers are free and the specialist and private centers are expensive. But they all welcome the revamping of the medical system wherein they can now change doctors (part of the new capitalistic influence nationwide). These women are eager to know more about help and are in midlife and are anxious for all publications to be printed in Russian. Physicians Attitudes and Knowledge: Family Planning and Menopause/Midlife There were six Russian participants, all were working as doctors at the medical institute. The average age was 29, and three of the doctors also had Ph.D.'s. There was an opening question of why we were there training and collaborating. We discussed what the problems were in women's healthcare today. Definitely, these female doctors were cognizant of the lack of knowledge and care for female issues in the medical arena. The education of the whole population is very poor or nonexistent in sexual matters, in family planning and in female gynecological issues. Women seem afraid of negative consequences for help in health or family planning. Their mothers have been skeptical and they don't have time to think about their health. The life of the Russian woman is tedious and complicated with difficulties economically and time crunches. The Russian women are more tired than the American women. Now you have 5 years to stay at home with a child and your job is reserved, but most women cannot afford to do this. There is a small, but growing group of housewives of businessmen who are electing to stay at home now. The problem of time and energy is overwhelming, and the women are crying for more flex time. Waiting in line for over an hour is an oppressive obstacle when one goes to the doctor because they do not have specific appointment times. Because of these time elements as well as societal taboos, illnesses are ignored in the first stages, so when the patients appear for help, they are usually in the more advanced stages. The doctors that are educated appreciate an informed, inquiring patient. But those not well educated, they are irritated with the patient and give misleading information about treatments. The problem with contraception is that the women will not return for pill evaluations, the condoms are not good and the IUD's are given only to the women with a child. Abortion is the last resort, but most Russian women resort to this method. The Russian women need personal doctors where they are followed for all of her life stages. Also, the doctors need to spend more time with their patients, educating them as well as providing treatment. Doctors need more autonomy so they can be in charge of their schedule and how they spend time with their patients. There are some doctors in the workplace but they are not gynecologists. They asked for more information, because they lack current medical journals. The need for hard currency reigns supreme. (The cost of an IUD is $10 for the first consultation and $15 to put it in. The cost of an abortion is $30 with an average starting salary of $25 a month.) They complained of primitive equipment and lack of pictures and pamphlets to educate themselves much less their patients. They asked for training in communication, in family relationship and sexuality and sexual pathology. They would welcome any psychology courses in women's issues. Click here to return to the ARHC Homepage or Russian Women's Healthcare This page, and all contents, are Copyright (C) 1994 by Mark Perloe, M.D., P.C. Atlanta, GA, USA. SLIM-Again(Garcinia cambogia) Super Formula Program TM How To Order Guaranteed Risk Free Or Call Us To Order At: 1-800-724-7546 ABOUT THE AUTHORS Muhammed Majeed, Ph.D. Editor Muhammed Majeed holds a Ph.D.(1986) in Industrial Pharmacy from St. John’s University inNew York. He has over 15 years of pharmaceutical researchexperience in the United States with leading companies such asPfizer, Inc., Carter-Wallace, and Paco Research. Dr. Majeed has abroad knowledge of the pharmacological properties of herbalmedicines used in Ayurveda, the traditional system of botanicalmedicine of India. He pioneered the introduction of such herbalremedies as Gugulipid®, Boswellin®, Picroliv®,Citrin®, Tylophora®, Centellin®, etc., for theAmerican and European markets. Anthony Conte, M.D. A leading physician in the field ofobesity, Dr. Conte has extensive experience as both a bariatricclinician and a principal investigator in research studies onappetite suppressants. In private practice in Hilton Head, SouthCarolina, Dr. Conte is an active member and a diplomate of theAmerican Society of Bariatric Physicians. Introduction Muhammed Majeed, Ph.D. Citrin® is the trade name given to a calcium salt of(-)-hydroxycitric acid [(-)HCA], a complex of the activeprinciple derived from Garcinia cambogia and Garcinia indicawhich are native to India. This product is standardized herbalextract derived from the pericarp of the Indian Berry (the rindof the fruit of Garcinia cambogia and Garcinia Indica). The storyof Citrin® revolves around the interlocking discoveries ofherbalists, botanists, and pharmaceutical scientists workingtogether to bring forth a revolutionary solution to an age-oldhuman dilemma -- the problem of how to achieve effective weightmanagement and reduce excess body fat. Through its novel and safemechanisms of action, Citrin® offers consumers and healthcare practitioners alike an effective dietary supplement foraccelerating fat-burning, inhibiting the formation of new fat,and promoting cardiovascular health. Super Formula Program TM How To Order Guaranteed Risk Free Or Call Us To Order At: 1-800-724-7546 (-)HCA and Weight Control During the 1970s, researchers at Brandeis University and atHoffman La Roche Laboratories discovered that fat synthesis couldbe blocked if citrate lyase were inhibited. In both test tubestudies and animal experiments, they demonstrated that(-)-hydroxycitrate impeded the biosynthesis of fats. Theinhibition of fat synthesis by (-)-hydroxycitrate occurred inliver cell cultures and in the livers of living rats which hadreceived this compound orally or by injection. Intrigued by thesefindings, the researchers speculated that (-)-hydroxycitratemight be advantageous for weight control. Further studies conducted by these researchers showed that theinclusion of (-)-hydroxycitrate into the diet of test animalsmarkedly suppressed weight gain in young, growing rats. Thissuppression of added weight resulted directly from the blockageof fat accumulation. It had no impact on the build-up of leanmass. Also, the effect was dose-dependent. The most impressivefindings were observed when (-)-hydroxycitrate accounted for onepercent or more of the diet. The (-)-hydroxycitrate used in theseexperiments was synthesized as a trisodium salt and administeredto the experimental animals in this form. When given an optimal intake of (-)-hydroxycitrate, the test ratstended to eat less, and their food consumption was suppressed by10 percent or more. This pattern of appetite suppression also wasseen in rats whose appetite-regulating centers in the brain hadbeen surgically destroyed. Furthermore, very little(-)-hydroxycitrate reached the brain. These findings stronglysuggest that the appetite-suppressive effect of this substance isnot centered in the brain (as is the case for manyappetite-curbing drugs). Rather, it is located in the liver. One of the chief functions of the liver is to ensure that theblood continually has adequate concentrations of glucose (sugar)to fuel the brain with energy. The brain cannot burn fat orprotein, only glucose. The first step in this process isgluconeogenesis, the complex reaction described earlier in whichglucose is formed from pyruvic acid. During gluconeogenesis,pyruvate also can be synthesized from non-carbohydrate molecules(such as lactate, glycerol, and amino acids -- the same buildingblocks that make up protein). The newly-manufactured glucose canthen either be released into the bloodstream or stored as energyreserve in the form of glycogen for future use. Acting as a barometer of liver glucose levels, the vagus nervelocated in the brain is linked to the liver. Specialized nervecells involved in this connection monitor the level of glucoseand glycogen in the liver. These nerve cells provide a mechanismfor appetite regulation. Thus, when liver glycogen stores arelow, such as after a fast or during famine, an animal iscompelled to eat a larger amount of food in order to feelsatiated, or full. The decision to eat more is under thephysiological control of nerve cell connections between the liverand the brain. Not surprisingly, the Hoffman La Roche scientists found that therate of gluconeogenesis nearly doubled in rats treated with(-)-hydroxycitrate. In other words, the rate at which the livercould manufacture glucose (in this case from lactate or the aminoacid, alanine) in the presence of (-)-hydroxycitrate was fasterthan occurred in control animals which did not receive thesupplement. This meant that the (-)-hydroxycitrate-treated ratsbecame satiated by consuming less food than did their untreatedcounterparts -- the control animals. The increased rate ofgluconeogenesis offered a solid explanation for the appetitesuppression observed in (-)-hydroxycitrate-treated animals. Yet,subsequent studies, though encouraging for weight control, failedto clarify the precise physiological mechanisms that couldaccount for weight loss. As noted previously, (-)-hydroxycitrate reduced appetiteconsiderably more than did many appetite-suppressive agents. In one study, at the end of 80 days, there was a four percent netreduction in food consumed by rats treated with(-)-hydroxycitrate. At the same time, however, these animals hadgained 78 percent less weight than the control animals which didnot receive any (-)-hydroxycitrate during this period. Thisobservation - the most dramatic one reported - along with otherfindings indicated that the relatively lower amount of weightgain was considerably less than expected, given the minimalchange that occurred in the animals’ food intake. In essence, the reduction in weight gain (78 percent) wasdisproportionately large when compared to the very small decreaseof four percent in food consumption. Similar findings emergedfrom a pair feeding study. When (-)-hydroxycitrate-treated ratsand control rats ingested identical quantities of food each day,the (-)-hydroxycitrate-treated rats gained substantially lessweight than did the controls. Hydoxycitrate had no obvious effecton the animals’ physical activity. It appears, therefore,that (-)-hydroxycitrate probably boosted the rats’ metabolicrate. Unfortunately, this hypothesis was never proven because thescientists failed to make any direct measurements of theanimals’ metabolic rate. The notion does, however, provide areasonable hypothesis for the mechanism through whichCitrin® --an herbal product containing the stable calciumsalt of (--hydroxycitrate -- inhibits the formation of new bodyfat. (-)HCA competes with citrate as asubstrate upon which the enzyme, citrate lyase, can act. In thepresence of (-)HCA, citrate cannot be easily converted intoacetyl Coenzyme A and oxaloacetate. The reduced availability ofthese two compounds subsequently alters other steps in theKreb’s Cycle that accelerate fat-burning in the liver. (-)HCA and Lipid Levels In an in vitro (test tube) study, the biosynthesis ofcholesterol dropped 27 percent in liver cells that had beenincubated with (-)-hydroxycitrate when compared to controlvalues. In a pre-clinical evaluation, serum triglyceride levelswere reduced in fructose-fed non-Zucker rats. The decrease inserum triglyceride levels were attributed to the ability of(-)-hydroxycitrate to increase the rate of fatty acid synthesisin the liver. The findings from these studies indicate thatCitrin® may be an efficacious dietary supplement for helpingto normalize elevated lipid levels. (-)HCA and Protein-Sparing In a negative calorie balance -- that is, when more caloriesare burned than ingested -- stored fat and protein are oxidizedto meet the body’s metabolic demands. It is preferable thatfat rather than protein be burned during this state. But, duringdieting (or restricted caloric intake), up to 30 percent of theweight reduction can result from the loss of lean protein-richtissues, especially skeletal muscle. As scientific studies haveshown, (-)HCA stimulates fat burning while at the same timeslowing the rate at which protein is oxidized. Consequently, theloss of lean tissue is minimized when (-)HCA is taken as adietary supplement during weight reduction programs. It is always important for the body to preserve lean tissue.Aside from its cosmetic or aesthetic appeal, lean mass iscritical for health because the basal metabolic rate is roughlyproportional to the amount of lean mass. During successfuldieting, lean mass is conserved. This enables the dieter tomaintain a steady rate of fat loss without having to drasticallyreduce the amount of food consumed. For those who do find it appropriate to diet, (-)HCA acceleratesthe loss of body fat without sacrificing excessive loss of leanmass. The probable protein-sparing benefits of Citrin® areamplified by an adequate but lower caloric intake of both proteinand complex carbohydrates. Most importantly, a dietary supplementof Citrin® can help to control appetite, stimulate metabolicrate, and spare the loss of protein in lean tissues. All of theseeffects in concert foster a rapid loss of fat, leading ultimatelyto a reduction in the percentage of body fat, and a slimmer,healthier, and leaner physique. CLINICAL EVALUATIONS OF (-)-HYDROXYCITRATE Anthony Conte, M.D. Bariatrics: The Medical Profession’s Approach ToObesity What is Bariatrician? A bariatrician is a physician who specializes in the diagnosis,prevention and medical treatment of obesity and diseases commonlyassociated with this condition such as diabetes, hypertension,arthritis, hypoglycemia, thyroid disorders and coronary disease.This subdivision of medical practice follows professionalstandards set forth by the American Society of BariatricPhysicians. Through research, continuing education, andinformation exchange, the members of this organization seek toencourage excellence in the practice of bariatrics. As abariatric physician in private practice for 30 years, I am alsoan active member and a diplomate of the American Society ofBariatric Physicians. In addition to my clinical practice oftreating individual patients, I have conducted over 20 clinicalstudies on appetite suppressants and meal replacement programs.Several of these studies, all of them performed in compliancewith FDA regulations, have been published in the medicalliterature. Obesity: The Orphan Disease "I find that the world is populated by fat peopletrying to get thin and by thin people trying to getthinner." This curious quote, still apropos for ourera, offered by an anonymous source appeared in a magazinearticle written in 1927. Despite the relevance of this statementfor today’s world, many people in the industrialized anddeveloping world alike apparently do not consider obesity aserious medical condition. But the importance of this condition cannot be overstated. TheJournal of the American Medical Association recently issued acall for American medicine to adopt obesity, an "orphandisease" (or a disease which the pharmaceutical industrytends to ignore) rather than leave it to benign neglect. Obesityaffects as many as 80 million people in the United States alone.Health statistics indicate that this disease causes a tremendousamount of psychological and familial suffering, as well as socialand economic turmoil. All of these factors directly andindirectly help to escalate the already accelerating health-carecosts in the United States. In fact, the overall impact of thiscondition ranks high on the list of national public healthproblems as well as personal health priorities. On any given day, 50 percent of American women and 25 percent ofAmerican men are dieting in one form or another. Their excessweight clearly exposes many of them to increased risk ofdeveloping clinical diabetes, hypertension, cardiovascularcomplications, including heart attacks and strokes, and otherdiseases that cost billions of dollars a year in medicalexpenses, lost work hours, and disability compensation. Despitethe magnitude of this problem, only recently has medical sciencebegan to take this issue seriously. Super Formula Program TM How To Order Guaranteed Risk Free Or Call Us To Order At: 1-800-724-7546 Weight-Loss Drugs (Anorexics) versus All-Natural Weight-Loss Enhancers As specialists concerned with the health risks and socialstigma associated with obesity, bariatricians are constantlystriving to find more effective and safer treatments for ourpatients. Fortunately, advances in basic medical science,including biochemistry, nutrition, and metabolism, have helped usto better understand the nature of obesity. A more detailedclarification of the body processes that control the distributionof fat and nutrients throughout various organs of the body mayfoster the development of novel approaches to this chronicproblem. In some patients, a medically approved appetite suppressant drugmay be the best solution. Just as encouraging a dependency ondiet pills is absurd, so too is it ludicrous to assume that everycase of obesity can and must be treated without medication.Bariatric physicians, therefore, are in continual search forgovernment approved, safe, and efficacious medications forobesity that can be used judiciously to treat those patients whocould benefit from such therapy. Drug development designed to combat obesity will entail afull-scale effort of basic and applied research by universityresearch scientists, pharmaceutical scientists in privateindustry, clinical physicians, nutritionists, allied healthprofessionals, and the developers of all-natural herbal extracts.The importance of the latter group, herbal researchers andmanufacturers, has been ignored and overshadowed for far too longin the field of weight management. In addition, the United States Government can assist in thedevelopment of safer and more efficacious treatments for obesityby assigning it a higher priority for government-sponsoredresearch funding. National public health education campaigns canelevate the consciousness of lay consumers about propernutrition, sensible eating habits, and other measures that mayhave a favorable impact on preventing many cases of obesity. Asbariatricians, those of us who have dedicated our lives to thisfield feel obligated to encourage other biomedical specialistsand researchers to become actively involved in this neglectedfield. I have participated in several clinical studies evaluating theefficacy and side-effects of anorexics: amphetamines,phendimetrazine, phentermine, mazindol, diethylproprion andphenylpropanolamine. Most consumers have heard of these drugsunder their various trade names. It is my experience that theseappetite suppressants can be safe and effective in a weightcontrol program when they are used selectively and monitoredcarefully by a knowledgeable physician. These medications shouldbe used only as a component of a well-planned,individually-designed or custom-tailored program that includes abalanced and sensible diet accompanied by appropriate physicalexercise. Yet, even medical professionals disagree over theoptimal length of time for which appetite suppressants should beused in a weight loss program. In my judgment, medication shouldnot be restricted to only 12 weeks out of a year if the patientrequires active treatment with pharmaceuticals for a longerperiod of time. Lengthy use of appetite-inhibiting or fat-burningdrugs can be appropriate if the therapy is free of adverse sidereactions and if it fosters healthier changes in lifestylehabits. In 1992, Dr. Michael Weintraub and his colleagues at theUniversity of Rochester School of Medicine concluded thatprescription appetite suppressants can help obese people to loseweight and keep weight off. Their four-year study demonstratedthat obesity should be treated as a chronic disease, comparableto high blood pressure and arthritis. The medical professionrecommends that in chronic diseases (often called the"diseases of civilization"), drugs can be takenindefinitely, if necessary, in order to minimize the symptoms.Yet, in spite of the medical justification for usingpharmaceuticals to treat certain cases of obesity, this does notmean that effective, alternative, or non-pharmaceutical methodsof treating this condition do not exist. They do, in fact, and Ihave spent many years of my professional career conductingresearch on the pros and cons of non-drug, all-natural appetitesuppressants. CLINICAL RESEARCH STUDIES Background During the last five years, I have conducted three studies onnatural weight-loss aids. All of these diet aids contained twoactive ingredients, (-)-hydroxycitrate (the active ingredient inCitrin®), and chromium (GTF). The results of all of thesestudies were impressive. (-)-Hydroxycitrate is the activeprinciple extracted from the rind of the fruit known as Garciniacambogia and Garcinia indica. In several pre-clinicalassessments, it has been shown to be an appetite suppressant aswell as a lipid lowering agent through its inhibition of fatsynthesis (or fatty acid production.) When (-)-hydroxycitrate is given as a supplement with meals,dietary carbohydrate seems more easily converted into glycogenwhich is then stored in the muscles and in the liver. The resultof these increased glycogen stores is enhanced stamina andendurance without any increase in body weight, especially bodystores of fat. On a biochemical level, the overall effect of(-)-hydroxycitrate is a reduction of acetyl Coenzyme A, the majorsource of carbon atoms available for the synthesis of lipids.(-)-Hydroxycitrate, therefore, lowers blood levels oftriglycerides and cholesterol, and it decreases body fat storeswithout causing a decline in energy output. Chromium (GTF) is a key mineral that "keeps insulin levelsin check" by making the hormone more efficient at regulatingblood sugar levels. In two clinical studies, patients wereadministered a combination of Citrin® (standardized tocontain 250 mg of the calcium salt of (-)-hydroxycitrate) and 100mcg of chromium. This supplement, which was taken three times aday, one half-hour before meals, is ideal because of thesynergistic actions that take place between (-)-hydroxycitrateand chromium. This combination represents a workable alternative to drugs usedfor weight loss. Beneficial to both the patients and thephysician, the Citrin®-Chromium Picolinate combination iscapable of enhancing any dietary and exercise program byfacilitating easier and more substantial weight loss. Of equalimportance, it does not interfere with the chemical actions ofother medications. Affordable in price and commercially availablethrough herbal manufacturers, it can be used by a widecross-section of individuals from different socio-economiclevels. Finally, my research consistently showed that compliancewith this treatment and the recommended diets was high in themajority of individuals who participated in my clinicalevaluations of this product. In all three of the following studies described below, thiscombination of weight loss enhancers, an herbal extractcontaining the calcium salt of (-)HCA and chromium, was used inconjunction with the Smart Choice Diet. I designed this diet as aspecial nutritional regimen to accompany theCitrin®-chromium supplement. The Smart Choice Diet consistsof low-fat, low-sugar, low-sodium foods eaten in three ordinarymeals. The overall program which I advocate combines the diet andweight loss enhancers with sensible daily exercise such aswalking. In most cases, it successfully led to gradual, safeweight loss that stayed off, decreased body fat, increased leanbody mass and, as a favorable side-effect, made for a healthier,happier lifestyle. The Hilton Head Study: Lipodex-2 In this eight-week, double-blind study conducted in 1991 inHilton Head Island, South Carolina, 54 subjects who participatedin the study were each seen weekly by me in my office. Over thecourse of the study period, Lipodex-2 (a supplement containing 50mg Garcinia cambogia extract and an amino acid chelate ofchromium and niacin) was taken by all 30 participants in the testgroup before each meal. The remaining 24 subjects took a placebo(an inert "sugar" pill) before they ate each meal. The 22 subjects in the test group who took Lipodex-2 lost anaverage of 11.1 pound per person, while the 17 subjects who tooka placebo dropped 4.2 pounds per person. All volunteers in thestudy were encouraged to adhere to the Smart Choice Diet,consisting of low-fat renditions of their usual meals, and drink64 ounces of water daily. The foods and the ways in which theywere prepared emphasized variety, moderation, and balance. All ofthe participants were encouraged to follow a daily regimen ofsensible and appropriate exercise. The Lipodex-2 group consistently showed better compliance withthe instructions for the program. They also had a higher level ofenergy, a greater level of appetite suppression, and reducedcravings for sweets than did the placebo group. Decreases in thelevels of serum cholesterol and triglyceride were also observed. The Allendale Study: Lipotrol/Actotherm This 8-week study, conducted in 1993, initially enrolled 128volunteers who were to take three different medications: 30participants were scheduled to receive Actotherm (a supplementwhich does not contain (-)-hydroxycitrate; 45 participants wereadministered a combination therapy of Lipotrol and Actotherm; and44 received Lipotrol. The procedures and instructions for this study were identicalto those used in the previously described Lipodex-2 study, withthe exception that placebos were not used in the Allendale study.Also, in contrast to the Hilton Head Study, individuals takingroutine medications were not excluded from the Allendale Study.Hunger levels were markedly depressed, energy levels increased,sugar cravings were reduced, and lipid levels were lowered inparticipants who took Lipotrol or a combination of Lipotrol andActotherm. In some cases, the changes in these variables weredramatic. Furthermore, no negative interactions were observedbetween the test supplements and other medications which some ofthe study volunteers were taking for other conditions. SAFETY OF CITRIN® Muhammed Majeed, Ph.D. Citrin® has been tested and approved by manufacturers inthe United States and Europe as a safe and efficacious product.It is the only herbal supplement derived from Garcinia cambogiato have undergone human clinical trials in the U.S.A. Its potencyis guaranteed through state-of-the-art HPLC. The LD50 Value of (-)HCA is > 2000 mg/kg for intraperitonialadministration and > 4000 mg/kg for oral administration.Tolerance to anorexic, or appetite suppressant drugs, usuallydevelops over time. This is a common feature in Central NervousSystem (CNS)-stimulant drugs such as amphetamines and otherphenylethylamine derivatives. In contrast, tolerance toCitrin® in pre-clinical studies was minimal. In oneinvestigation, (-)-hydroxycitrate continued to lower the amountof food consumed through the 80-day duration of the trial. Otheranorexic agents such as Fenfluramine were effective for appetiteonly after the first few days, but not beyond that period oftime. (-)-Hydroxycitrate does not affect respiration, phosphorylation,or the citrate synthesis of the reconstituted mitochondria. Thiscompound lowers the rate of lipogenesis (or the rate at which thebody forms new fat) in a dose-dependent manner in the liver,adipose (fat) tissue, and the small intestine. However,(-)-hydroxycitrate neither penetrates the mitochondria noraffects normal energy production. As an herbal product containing standardized (-)HCA, Citrin®offers a safe alternative to appetite-suppressant substances thatoveractivate the sympathetic nervous system, produce only shortterm anorexia, and carry the risk of being addictive. Unlikepharmaceutical agents and most other nutrient and herbal productson the market, Citrin® decreases food intake, diminishesappetite, and accelerates the burning of fatty acids withoutadverse side effects. These features make Citrin® a viablechoice for efficaciously treating obesity and overweightness. WEIGHT CONTROL: A BARIATRICIAN’S POINT OF VIEW Anthony Conte, M.D. Why Do Some People Get Fat While Others Don’t? There is an increasing number of theories Ñ most ofthem speculative Ñ about weight gain and the manner inwhich calories are ingested and burned. We are all aware of themany non-obese people who overeat, especially consuming hugequantities of carbohydrates, for extended periods of time withoutgaining any weight. However, even in individuals who maintainstable weight, this pattern ultimately is costly to normalhealth. Given a long enough period of time, excessive intake ofcarbohydrates will lead to excess storage of body fat. Thisoccurs because over consumption of glucose-containing foodsincreases the body’s production of lipogenic, orfat-storing, enzymes such as lipoprotein lipase (LPL). Once thischemical action can be safely blocked without disrupting any ofthe body’s other normal processes, then most weight problemscan be brought under control. Simple refined sugars, including fructose which is often toutedas a natural sugar since it is found in fruit, are always aproblem for weight management. Indeed, there is growing evidencethat fructose stimulates lipogenesis, or fat storage, even morethan does glucose. White sugar is composed of two glucosemolecules joined together. Fructose is converted even morerapidly into glucose than is white, or refined sugar. Fructose,present in fruit juices, corn syrups, and many so-called"health food products," causes an unhealthy rise in thelevels of liver enzymes, insulin, and blood triglycerides. Physical activity is of course critical to proper weightmanagement. Metabolic rate, the ratio of lean to fatty body mass,and genetic factors (or individual heredity) in combination withphysical activity have bearing on how successful -- orunsuccessful body fat reduction will be. Equally important toweight management are the degree, duration, and timing ofovereating. When physical exercise is closely coupled with thetiming of excessive eating, then the negative consequences ofpotential weight gain are minimized. People who diet withoutexercising tend to lose mainly water and in some cases, muscletissue; but, individuals who exercise and eat a sensible andbalanced diet low in simple sugars are able to effectively shedexcess weight, and, most importantly, keep it off for sustainedperiods of time. I have used various Citrin®-based products to treat numerouscases of overweightness in my medical practice. I have foundunequivocally from the case studies I have followed and theclinical studies I have conducted that Citrin® is a safe andeffective natural alternative to allopathic drugs for promotingweight loss. Super Formula Program TM How To Order Guaranteed Risk Free Or Call Us To Order At: 1-800-724-7546 Myths Versus Facts in Obesity: A Reality Check In my practice as a bariatrician, I often have to dispel mythsthat seem to persist in the face of growing scientific evidence.Frequently, I am asked recurrent questions relating to weightloss. These myths and questions come up so often from patientsthat I thought it worthwhile to present them here with what Ithink are realistic responses or counter-proposals. It is hopedthat the factual rebuttals to common myths, or misconceptions,about dieting and weight loss and the answers to common queriesabout this subject will assist the reader in choosing a weightmanagement program that is optimal for him or her. Common Myths About Losing Weight Myth: Prescription "diet pills"are bad for you. Fact: As is the case for all drugs, diet pillscan be beneficial if used with proper judgment and if monitoredby a trained medical professional. The selection of anappropriate medication, the dosage, and the duration of its useshould be monitored by a qualified physician who evaluates itsappropriateness on the basis of the patient’s degree ofexcess weight, overall health needs, eating patterns, andlifestyle. Myth: A diet pill makes you lose weight. Fact: Diet medication does not make a personlose weight. However, because it suppresses appetite, it may helpa person avoid cravings and eat less. A sensible eating strategythat is easy to "stick to" must consist of variety,moderation and balance. A diet is essentially a lifestylemodification -- a gradual change in eating habits thatincorporates the proper mix of proteins, fruits, vegetables,grains, and dairy products for optimal nutrition, lean body mass,and preventive medicine. Radical departures from normal eatinghabits, such as following a very low calorie diet or ingesting a"milkshake" diet as a replacement for every meal arenot sensible courses of action to follow. These practicesrepresent unnatural ways of eating, quickly leaving dietersbored, frustrated, and ready to sacrifice their will power. Myth: Fasting is the best way to loseweight. Fact: Fasting for more than four days withoutmedical supervision can damage kidney and liver functions andchange the chemical balance in the blood. Weight loss throughfasting is more apt to be retained because it results from a"crash diet" effect rather than from developingsensible eating habits. Myth: Calories do not count. Fact: Yes, Calories do count. Excess weightresults from eating, or taking in, more calories than a personexpends as energy in exercise and other daily physicalactivities. If a person uses up more calories than he takes in,he loses weight. However, not all calories are created equal, as shown in thefollowing table: Calorie Source Calories per Gram Carbohydrate .................. 4 Protein ............................ 4 Alcohol .......................... 7 Fat .................................. 9 Whenever possible, it is advisable to eat carbohydrates andproteins instead of fats. A full 98 percent of the caloriecontent of fat goes into storage as body fat, and only twopercent is used in digestion. In contrast, complex carbohydratesand proteins burn up 23 percent of their total calorie content inthe process of digestion. Myth: Everyone who loses weight gains it allback sooner or later. Fact: Long-term weight loss is possible, but itrequires that a person learn new ways of eating and living. Itmeans making a lifetime commitment to a safe and clinicallyeffective program (which, in some people, will involve carefulmonitoring by clinical staff). There is no "quick fix"to improving one’s health and appearance. In order to besuccessful, an individual must have perseverance and unstintingdetermination to reach and maintain his or her desired weight andshape. Only the dieter can make it happen. Ask a Bariatrician. The Questions I Hear Most Often Question #1: Are there any"secrets" to weight-loss and maintenance? Response #1: The answers are all too obvious -eat right, eat light, and exercise. Too often people adopt afrantic, "Lose It Now" mentality to weight loss as theyunrealistically seek instant results. But slimming down for goodis a gradual process. Slow weight loss occurs over months as aperson learns to adapt to the changes of a new and improvedlifestyle. Question #2: Only one in 12 people can loseweight and keep it off. Why do so many people fail? Response #2: The most common cause of failurestems from the daily ritual of stepping onto the scale, notseeing "instant" results, and becoming discouraged atthe lack of an immediate drop of that little pointer.Unfortunately, many people give up entirely because they miss themost important goals of weight loss. The true goal should be tolose excess fat while not sacrificing lean body mass. Healthyweight loss should improve all bodily functions and be free ofdehydration, or loss of body fluids. About 73 percent of people who design their own diets instead ofusing a formal program lose weight and keep it off. I believethis occurs because people on self-designed diets include many oftheir favorite foods (though perhaps in smaller amounts).Including foods they enjoy makes it easier for them to complywith their own self-regulated weight management programs. Inaddition, when individuals develop their own diet plans, theytend to set more modest, realistic goals for themselves that makeit easier to adhere to changes in eating habits. Question #3: Why do so many diets includeeight glasses of water a day? Response #3: A vital component of a weight lossdiet is an adequate intake of water. When the body burns 16ounces of fat, it generates about 22 ounces of water which mustbe flushed. The ideal way to do this is to drink more water. If aperson drinks less than 64 ounces of water, his body reacts tothis as a threat to survival, and therefore holds on to everydrop. Some of the unfortunate consequences of this are swellingin the feet, ankles, legs, and hands, as well as a slowing downin the rate at which weight drops. Question #4: Does exercise increaseappetite? Response #4: No. Studies have shown that thelevel of appetite is greatest in a sedentary person or when aperson exercises strenuously; but, the appetite fallsdramatically to a very low level when a person exercisesmoderately. As in designing one’s own diet, one’schoice of exercise ideally should be something enjoyable, fun,and realistic. A person is more likely to engage in an exerciseroutine on an ongoing basis if he likes it. The goal of exerciseshould not be strenuous, but rather regular, graded, vigorousphysical activity. By improving circulation, exercise stimulatesthe body while reducing both bodily and psychological stress.Exercise burns up excess calories, builds lean body tissue,lowers fat in the blood, and helps to stabilize blood sugar. Question #5: What about medically supervisedliquid diet programs (VLCD) that we hear about celebrities using? Response #5: These sorts of diets originallywere intended for people who are at least 40 pounds overweight(or more than 30 percent above their recommended weight). Suchdiets are potentially dangerous, however. They should beundertaken only with medical supervision and should not continuebeyond 12 weeks. The cost of these programs can be very high, averaging as much as$180 for every pound of weight loss. When one adds to this costthe fact that nearly all patients following these types of dietregained most of their weight, it suggests that they are notoptimal weight management plans. This finding again shows that aweight loss program must involve fundamental changes in eatinghabits with which an individual can live comfortably for the restof his or her life. Question #6: Are new drugs being developedfor the treatment of obesity? Response #6: Yes. As the medical professionamasses more knowledge of the body mechanisms involved inobesity, we gain insights into new approaches that may help toremedy this condition. The use of complementary drugs -- such asdigestive aids, lipolytic agents, metabolic correctors,thermogenic substances, and nutritional supplements -- inconjunction with medical care offer new and potentially rewardingtherapeutic regimens for obesity. Question #7: What is Orlistat? Why was itcalled a "dream drug?" Response #7: Orlistat (its chemical name istetrahydrolipstatin), developed by Hoffman-LaRoche Laboratoriesappears to have the same properties as an appetite suppressantand a lipid lowering agent as does (-)-hydroxycitrate, the activeingredient in Citrin®. This is not surprising in light ofthe fact that the early experimental work conducted on animalsgiven (-)-hydroxycitrate was done at Hoffman LaRoche Laboratoriesin the 1970s. However, because (-)-hydroxycitrate, as an extractof a natural product, could not be patented at that time,research on this molecule may have been halted. It is noteworthythat researchers at this major pharmaceutical company are nowresuming their studies on (-)-hydroxycitrate as a model for apatentable, "synthetic" pharmaceutical agent. In a recent study, 100 Americans who took Orlistat and followed alight diet lost an average of 11 pounds over a three monthperiod. This weight loss was nearly twice as much as the weightloss that occurred in the control group. Our own results with Citrin®, a commercial productcontaining (-)-hydroxycitrate, and chromium in clinicalevaluations have shown a similar weight loss in eight weeks. Sideeffects were not observed in subjects taking Citrin®,regardless of the medications they may have been taking at thesame time. An ambitious two-year study on Orlistat involving4,000 subjects in Europe and the United States is currentlyunderway. Since clinical trials must be conducted over a longperiod of time, it may be several years before Orlistat isapproved for sale in the United States. Moreover, if and when itdoes, it will be available by prescription only. In the interim,a safe and efficacious, all-natural product, Citrin®, whichmay be at least as effective as Orlistat for body fat reductionand weight loss, is currently on the market. Question #8: There seems to be manydifferent all-natural weight loss enhancers. How do I know whichcompanies offer genuine products? Response #8: Assessing the legitimacy andauthenticity of claims made about various products is an ongoingprocess. I suggest that the consumer carefully read labels,scrutinize the level of scientific assertions made by the companyand its researchers, and consult with a medically trainedphysician or health professional. An interested individual shouldnot be afraid to call or write to the manufacturer with hisquestions. An honest firm will be glad to answer questions andadmit any limitations or inconclusive findings about theirproducts. In addition, it is appropriate to request from amanufacturer copies of research studies evaluating the qualityand effects of the weight-loss product. References Lewis, Y.S. and Neelakantan, S., 1965.
