Absorbit-ALL PLUS™ Konjac Glucomannan (Amorphophallus konjac) Super Formula Program TM How To Order Guaranteed Risk Free Or Call Us To Order At: 1-800-724-7546 Effect of Glucomannan in Obese Patients (A Clinical Study) David E. Walsh, Ph.D. Vazgen Yaghoubian, Ph.D. Research Department General Nutrition Corporation Fargo, North Dakota ABSTRACT Health problems common in the United States such as obesity,diverticular disease and heart attacks are practically unknown inparts of the world where more food fiber is eaten. It is wellknown that proper amounts of dietary fiber can aid in bowelregularity. Since dietary fiber is not assimilated by the body,it contributes no calories and can help a person lose weight andkeep it off once the desired weight is reached. Control ofobesity is extremely important since it has been linked to adultonset diabetes, high blood pressure, and other health problems.Also, certain dietary fibers have been shown to help reduce andalleviate high cholesterol in the blood. A double blind study compared glucomannan fiber supplementagainst a method placebo in obese patients. Patients were giveninstructions to use the supplement or placebo for weightreduction. Over a 4-week period a highly significant weight lossof 5.3 pounds occurred in 10 obese patients who supplementedtheir diet with glucomannan. Serum cholesterol, triglycerides,and LDL were lowered over an 8-week period when 3 gm/day ofglucomannan were taken. INTRODUCTION Glucomannan is a component of the Konjac root, a food used inJapan. For over 1000 years Konjac (Amorphophallus konjac) hasbeen cultivated and eaten in Japan and parts of China. Commonfoods such as sukiyaki use Konjac in the form of noodles. Otheruses for Konjac are as a food thickener and jelly. The main constituent of Konjac jelly is glucomannan whichaccounts for 10% of the total dry material. Purified glucomannanis prepared by washing. Starch, protein, and water-solublematerials are removed to yield 60-90% pure glucomannanpreparation. Glucomannan is a high molecular weight carbohydratethat chemically resembles cellulose. However, while celluloseconsists almost entirely of glucose molecules linked by beta b1-4 saccharide bonds, glucomannan consists of glucose and mannosemolecules linked by beta b 1-4 bonds. These small chemicaldifferences account for the unique physical properties ofglucomannan. Cellulose is insoluble and absorbs only 5 to 10times its weight in water, while glucomannan is soluble andabsorbs as much as 200 times its weight in water. Glucomannan when mixed with water forms a viscous solution. In a1-2% solution, glucomannan will have a viscosity of over 100,000centipoise. The viscosity of glucomannan increases slowly for amaximum viscosity at 5 hours. Consequently when used as a dietarysupplement, people are advised to take glucomannan from 1/2 hourup to 2 hours before meals with 8 ounces of water. This allowstime for water absorption, gel formation, and proper dispersion. Glucomannan acts as a dietary fiber to increase viscosity andmoisture content of the food bolis during digestion. The foodmixes with the viscous glucomannan to form a smooth, soft masswhich easily moves through the gastrointestinal tract. Sinceglucomannan forms a nondigestible coating around food particles,food is digested at a slower rate. The gel slows the action ofdigestive enzymes to release sugars and fats at an even rate.This effect is desirable in treating obesity and diabetesmellitus. The bulk-forming property of glucomannan helps fill the stomachto satisfy the appetite. Because digestion is slowed, large highsin blood glucose are avoided and normal blood sugar levels aremaintained after a meal. This aids in controlling overeating andhelps fight the "snack attacks" which occur when bloodglucose drops 2 hours after a meal. With glucomannan (and someother food fibers) gradual digestion "times release" ofsugar helps maintain sugar at normal levels without wide swings in blood levels. Super Formula Program TM How To Order Guaranteed Risk Free Or Call Us To Order At: 1-800-724-7546 Japanese workers have had good results in treating diabetes withglucomannan. Sugar absorption was slowed and blood sugar levelswere reported stabilized when glucomannan was used in the dietsof noninsulin dependent diabetics. It is well known that certain dietary fibers absorb cholesterol,bile acid, and lipids. Glucomannan's gel-forming propertiespromote absorption of fats and reduce serum cholesterol andtriglycerides. Japanese researchers reported glucomannan hadhypocholesterolemic properties in rat feeding trials. In elderlyhumans significant decreases in serum cholesterol, triglycerides,and free fatty acids were reported when glucomannan was added tothe diet. Two-thirds of these elderly patients also reported thatglucomannan had anticonstipation properties. MATERIALS AND METHODS In the present study 20 patients (10 obese and 10 not obese)were given a glucomannan supplement and 20 (10 obese and 10 notobese) given a placebo. Strict adherence was given to doubleblind procedures. Neither patients nor dietitians who interviewedpatients were informed as to what the capsule contained. Eachpatient was given the same brand of Glucomannan capsules or aplacebo and was instructed to take 2 capsules 3 times per daywith 8 ounces of water 2 hours before meals. Each capsulecontained 500 mg of purified Glucomannan from Konjac root. The 10obese patients were informed that they were testing a weightreduction supplement. All patients were to eat their regularmeals. The supplement was intended to help curb appetite andenable them to eat less for weight loss. No special diet wasgiven. Blood samples were drawn at the beginning, at 4 weeks, and at theend of the 8 week test period. Serum cholesterol, triglycerides,high density lipoproteins, low density lipoproteins, and uricacid levels were determined. Patients were given physical examsto establish general health. Once a week each patient wasinterviewed by a dietitian, weighed, and blood pressuredetermined. WEIGHT LOSS Table 1, below, shows weight change data for 20 obesepatients: 10 who took glucomannan and 10 who were given a placebofor 4 weeks. All 10 glucomannan patients lost weight. The largestweight loss with glucomannan was patient E, a 180 pound femalewho lost 12 pounds. The least weight loss with glucomannan wasfor patient J, a 158 pound female who lost only 1.75 pounds in 4weeks. An average weight loss of 5.33 pounds in 4 weeks wasshown. Most of the glucomannan patients observed that they had afeeling of fullness and less than usual hunger. No reports ofdiarrhea, constipation, or other adverse effects were reported bythe glucomannan supplemented group. Weight changes for the placebo group were also reported in Table1. This group showed fluctuations in weight from a gain of 6.25pounds to a loss of 5 pounds in 4 weeks. An average insignificantweight loss of 0.35 pounds is shown for the placebo group. Withthe placebo most patients reported no feeling of fullness orother effect. In fact it was difficult to keep patients fromdropping out of the placebo group because they had seen little orno effect. By contrast, the glucomannan group were quiteenthusiastic and many asked if they could continue using thesupplement after the clinical trial was completed. CHOLESTEROL DATA Serum cholesterol analyses were done on a group of 18 patientsover an 8-week period. The group was selected to cover a range ofnormal to high (150-300 mg/dl). Figure 1 shows the average of 18patients who had taken glucomannan. This data showed decline incholesterol over an 8-week period from 210 to 200 mg/dl. Sincethe average patient had a low or normal cholesterol, littledecrease was expected. However, when 14 patients with moderate cholesterol of 200 mg/dlor more were studied, the average cholesterol showed asignificant decrease from 220 mg/dl to 190 mg/dl in 18 weeks(Figure 2). Even more dramatic was the decrease in cholesterolfor the 2 patients who had high cholesterol levels greater than250 mg/dl (Figure 3). These patients decreased from an average of270 mg/dl to 215 mg/dl after taking glucomannan for 8 weeks. The20 patients on the placebo increased slightly in cholesterol 2mg/dl for the same 4 and 8 week periods. Super Formula Program TM How To Order Guaranteed Risk Free Or Call Us To Order At: 1-800-724-7546 LOW DENSITY LIPOPROTEIN (LDL) DATA Low density lipoproteins (LDL) are associated with cholesterolin arteriosclerosis and are a risk factor in heart attacks. A lowlevel of serum LDL is desirable and is a measure of good health.Of 18 patients who used glucomannan, the average LDL decreasedsteadily over 8 weeks from 145 mg/dl to 130 mg/dl (Figure 4).Because the average LDL was within the normal range change wasexpected. However for the 4 patients with high LDL, a highlysignificant decrease in LDL was observed during an 8-week periodwhen glucomannan was used as a diet supplement (Figure 5). Theaverage LDL decreased from 190 mg/dl to 145 mg/dl by the end ofthe 8 week clinical test for the high LDL group. The 20 patientsusing the placebo showed no significant change in LDL over 8weeks. They dropped 4 mg the first week and gained 1 mg LDL ateight weeks. High density lipoproteins (HDL) did not change withglucomannans supplementation compared with the patients. However,the nature of HDL to LDL was significantly improved because LDLdecreased when the glucomannan was used. TRIGLYCERIDES DATA Serum triglycerides were determined for 18 patients over an8-week period. The presence of triglycerides in the blood is ameasure of the amount of calories provided by fats in the diet.High fat diets tend to elevate serum triglycerides. Certainweight loss diets also have shown high serum triglyceridesbecause body fat is being used as a predominant source ofcalories. In my experience serum triglycerides change very littlewith high proteins or fructose diets that I have tested in thepast. However, a significant change with glucomannan was notedover an 8-week period. The average for 18 patients showed a smalldecrease from 110 mg/dl in 8 weeks (Figure 6). However, 7patients who had elevated triglycerides showed a highlysignificant decrease in serum triglycerides from 170 mg/dl to 145mg/dl over an 8-week period (Figure 7). The placebo group had nosignificant change in triglyceride in 4-week (-1 mg at 4 weeks,+0.1 mg at 8 weeks). SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS A double blind clinical trial of glucomannan food fiber wasconducted. Two groups of 10 obese patients were given glucomannanor a placebo over a 4-week period. The results showed that theglucomannan supplemented group lost an average of 5.3 lbs/4weeks, while the placebo group showed no significant weight loss.No diet plan was given to either group. Patients were instructedto take 2 capsules 3 times per day with 8 ounces of water 2 hoursbefore meals. In other tests serum cholesterol, low density lipoproteins, andtriglycerides showed highly significant decreases when patientstook glucomannan over an 8-week period. In addition, constipationwas relieved, and no adverse reactions to glucomannan wereobserved. For the results of this double-blind clinical trial, it wasconcluded that glucomannan (3 gm/day) was beneficial as a foodfiber supplement. Glucomannan functions as an aid to weight lossin obese patients. Cholesterol, triglycerides, and LDL serumlevels are significantly lowered in patients with elevated serumlipid levels. Moreover, glucomannan appeared to be a safe andhighly effective food fiber supplement. Super Formula Program TM How To Order Guaranteed Risk Free Or Call Us To Order At: 1-800-724-7546 REFERENCES 1. HYPOCHOLESTEROLEMIC ACTIVITY AND MOLECULAR WEIGHT OF KONJAC MANNAN Shuhachi Kiriyama, Akiko Enishi and Akira Yoshida ABSTRACT Effect of species, cultivation district and preparation on thehypocholesterolemic activity of crude konjac mannan (CKM) wasstudied when CKM was added at the 3% level to ahypercholesterolemic diet. Activity was correlated with themolecular weight and molecular shape or size of KM. The mostactive variety was CKM obtained from Shina-shu (Chinese species)harvested in Gumma Prefecture, followed by Zairai-shu (Domesticspecies) harvested in Saitama Prefecture and Zairai-shu harvestedin Fukushima Prefecture. Bitchu-shu, a variation of the domesticspecies, harvested in Gumma Prefecture exhibited no activity. Themolecular weight of Shina-shu was about 2 X 106 and that ofBitchu-shu, 7 X 105; the radii of gyration (RG) of these two KMmolecules which showed two extremes in activity were about 2300 Aand 1000 A, respectively. Other CKM samples tested ranged between9 - 12 X 105 in molecular weight and 1000 - 1300 A in RG. Theseresults suggest that molecular weight and shape or size of KM inaqueous solution are closely related to its hypocholesterolemicactivity. Tentatively, we have concluded that activity may berealized if molecular weight and RG of KM molecules are above 8 -9 X 105 and 1000 A, regardless of species, cultivation districtand preparation methods. INTRODUCTION The original habitat of Amorphophallus plants is thought to beSoutheast Asia. At the present, these plants grow in thetropical, sub-tropical and temperate zones of Asia includingJapan. However, a few species are cultivated only in Japanbecause edible "Konnyaky" is needed as a habitualfoodstuff of Japanese people. In other areas of Asia (China,Indonesia, Burma, Thailand and Indo-China) the plants grow wild.The tubers of Amorphophallus konjac contain a large amount of mannan (konjac mannan), which can be separated gravitationallyafter crushing the dried tuber slices from other components.Ohtsuki1 has shown that the tubers of Amorphophallus konjaccontain 20% of dry matter which yields about 64% of mannan and10.6% of starch. The total production of CKM in Japan isestimated at about 10,000 - 12,000 tons per year. CKM obtained bytraditional separation methods sometimes results in low molecularweight samples because enzymatic depolymerization may occurduring drying of tuber slices in the sun. KM with high molecularweight is obtained by homogenizing the tubers with an equal partof ethanol and by separating it gravitationally. CKM did not lose its original activity even after extensivepurification. CKM, partially purified (PPKM) and highly purified(HPKM) konjac mannan completely lost their plasma cholesteroldepressing activity when treated with cellulase. Moreover, thebeneficial effect of CKM, PPKM or HPKM supplemented to ahypercholesterolemic diet was also completely canceled by thedietary addition of cellulase. Therefore, various low molecularcontaminants in CKM do not appear to contribute to the activityof CKM. It became increasingly apparent that an active principlein CKM is KM itself, and that KM must be water soluble andmacromolecular in order to exhibit its hypocholesterolemiceffect. The hypocholesterolemic activity of CKM was completely eliminatedwhen it was irreversibly coagulated to a water insoluble form bymixing it with small amounts of milk of lime and when it washydrolyzed in 0.2 N HCl at 100ºC for 12 hours, neutralizedand then lyophilized.2 Therefore, we have suggested that theactive substance should be a main constituent, KM, retaining boththe water soluble and macromolecular property. A series of facts concerning the hypocholesterolemic activity ofKM suggests that there may be a close correlation betweenphysiological activity and molecular weight of KM. On the otherhand, the quality of edible "Konnyaku" has been knownto depend upon the species of Amorphophallus konjac, cultivationdistrict and preparation method of CKM from the tubers. Physicalproperties of the rigid gel produced from KM by mixing a weakalkaline solution are widely different depending on thesefactors. These facts also suggest that there are considerabledifferences in molecular weight and/or the shape of KM molecules. We compared the hypocholesterolemic activity of various CKMdiffering in origin and preparation method and attempted tocorrelate the physiological activity with molecular weight and/ormolecular shape of KM. MATERIALS AND METHODS Male rats of the Wistar strain weighing about 100 g were usedthroughout the experiment. After the animals were maintained on astock diet for 3 to 5 days, they were divided into groups of 5rats each and then fed test diets for 7 days. At the end of theexperimental period, blood was drawn by heart puncture withheparinized syringes under Nembutal anaesthesia. The liver wasrapidly excised and plasma and liver total cholesterol weredetermined by the method of Pearson and associates.3 The basal (normal) diet used was of the following composition:casein, 20%; corn oil 5%; salt mixture, 4%; vitamin mixturetriturated in lactose, 1%; choline chloride, 0.2%; and themixture of 1:1 pregelatinized corn starch and sucrose, 70.8%. Thehypocholesterolemic diet (control) was the basal dietsupplemented with 1% cholesterol and 0.25% sodium cholate. Testdiets were those in which each test CKM was added at the 3% levelto the control diet. The experiment was divided into threesimilar trials. The animals used in experiments 1 and 2 werepurchased on the same date, the latter experiment being startedwith a one-day delay after experiment 1. Experiment 3 wasinitiated 10 days after the end of experiment 2. RESULTS AND DISCUSSION The results obtained in the three experiments are summarizedin Table 1. In experiment 1, only Shina-shu (Gumma) significantlydecreased plasma cholesterol levels as compared with the controlgroup (127 mg/100 ml vs. 198 mg/100 ml). This 36% decrease inplasma cholesterol could not be attributed to the decrease infood intake because the animals fed Shina-shu consumedapproximately the same amount of diet (19.6 g/day) as the controlgroup (17.0 g/day). A clear parallelism between plasma and livercholesterol levels was also observed. In experiment 2, all samples showed significant plasmacholesterol depressing activity except Zairai-shu (Gumma).Zairai-shu harvested in Hiroshima Prefecture appeared most activeof all samples and resulted in a 32% decrease in plasmacholesterol from the controls. There was no significantdifference in food intake or body weight gain between rats fedthe control and Zairai-shu (Hiroshima) diets. Here again,parallelism between plasma and liver cholesterol levels is seen.Although there was no statistically different change between ratsfed Zairai-shu (Gumma) and the control diet in plasma cholesterollevels, this appears to be due to the large deviation in thevalues of the former. For example, the average plasma cholesterolvalue of the rats fed Zairai-shu (Nagano) was about the same (140mg/100 ml) as that of the animals eating Zairai-shu (Gumma) whichwas 139 mg/100 ml; and this was significantly lower than that ofthe control group. In experiment 3, only Zairai-shu (Fukushima) significantlydepressed plasma cholesterol level (143 mg/100 ml as compared tothe control value of 198 mg/100 ml). This decrease amounts to28%. Since the three experimental conditions differed slightlyfrom each other, the plasma cholesterol values obtained cannot bedirectly compared, and per cent decrease as compared with eachcontrol value would be a reasonable measure for relativecomparison. Accordingly, the order of activity is as follows:Shina-Shu (Gumma) > Zairai-shu (Hiroshima) > Zairai-shu(Fukushima). Konjac mannans in several samples tested were purified and theirmolecular weights and radii of gyration in aqueous solution weredetermined according to the procedure of Sugiyama and co-workers4using the light scattering method.5 As shown in Figure 1, themolecular weight of Shina-shu which was most hypocholesterolemicwas about 2 X 105 and its RG about 2000 A. In contrast, themolecular weight of Bitchu-shu (Gumma), which had no activity,was about 7 X 105, approximately 1/3 that of Shina-shu. It appears that molecular weight and/or spreading shape in theaqueous solution plays a significant role in physiologicalactivity of KM. Almost all other samples used ranged betweenthese 2 extremes: molecular weight, 9 - 12 X 105 and RG, about1000 - 14000 A. These delicate differences among ordinary KMsamples could not be distinguished by the present animalexperiments. Therefore, plasma cholesterol values of rats fedthese intermediate KM samples varied from each other depending onthe experiment regardless of their order of molecular weight andradius of gyration. As previously reported (2), it may bereasonable to assume from the fluidity of the cellulasehydrolysate of KM that its molecular weight is much smaller thanthat of intact KM and inactive as an hypocholesterolemic agent. From the present and previous results, it would appear that theactive principle in CKM is KM itself, hypocholesterolemicactivity of KM occurs when its molecular weight and RG are above8 - 8 X 105 and above 1000 A respectively, and when the watersoluble property is retained intact in KM. EFFECT OF GLUCOMANNAN (KONJAC FIBER) ON GLUCOSE AND LIPID METABOLISM IN NORMAL AND DIABETIC SUBJECTS Kunihiro Doi, Masaaki Matsuura, Akira Kawara, RinzoUenoyama, and Shigeaki Baba RESULTS AS STATED IN THE CONCLUSION Recently, dietary fibers have been used successfully to allowthe use of lower dosages of insulin or hypoglycemic agents in thetreatment of diabetics. These fibers considered to increase theviscosity of the gastrointestinal contents, thus slowing gastricemptying and forming around the food a barrier that delays itsabsorption by the intestinal wall (Jenkins et al., 1978). Theirviscosity appears to be a major factor in eventually suppressing,through this mechanism, the postprandial rise of the bloodglucose level. Guar gum (galactomannan), since it was thought to be the mostviscous of the dietary fibers, was regarded as the most effectivein reducing hyperglycemia. However, our data show that theviscosity of glucomannan is far higher than that of any otherfibers. The suppression by glucomannan of the postprandial riseof glucose and insulin levels was more pronounced than that byguar gum when added to the glucose solution or test meal, andmost pronounced when glucomannan was mixed into the test meal. Although the amount of glucomannan used in thisexperiment was rather small, the results were good. Some of thereasons for this have yet to be clarified, but one factor is itsvery high viscosity. Moreover, its ability to absorbcarbohydrates, lipids and other high-calorie substances in thestomach and the small intestine is the greatest among all thedietary fibers. The serum levels of cholesterol and bile acids decreased whenglucomannan was used, but after 1 or 2 months, the serumcholesterol levels increased for a short time. One possibleexplanation of this phenomenon is that the enterohepaticcirculation of the bile acids and cholesterol was interrupted bythe absorption of these substances in the intestine byglucomannan, which was followed by a decrease in their serumlevels. As a homeostatic response, then, the production ofcholesterol in the liver may have increased for a short period. We did not observe the serum bile acid levels over a long period,but it is presumed that, as with cholesterol, they also increasedfor a while 2 or 3 months after glucomannan was taken, and thenfell again. Serum Cu++, Fe++, Na+, K+ and Cl- levels of 6 diabetics werefollowed, but no significant increase or decrease was observed. The postprandial blood glucose concentrations were lower when thesubjects were fed fiber-supplemented diets, and in some of them,also the body weight decreased. There were some complaints ofshort-lived side effects such as nausea and discomfort whenlarger doses of glucomannan were given. The effects of dietary fibers on glucose metabolism may be usefulin the control of the diet and of the drug dosage of diabetics,especially for non-insulin-dependent diabetics or obese subjects.Further study is necessary in order to discover the metabolic andphysiological effects of these viscous forms of dietary fiber. Baba The Second Department of Internal Medicine Kobe University School of Medicine Kobe 650 Japan ABSTRACT Epidemiological observations suggested that diabetics,hyperlipidermia and coronary heart disease might be related todeficient fiber. Therefore much interest has been shown in thepossibility of treating diabetics with fiber-rich diets. We have been studying to treat diabetics with soluble fiber,Konjac mannan (glucomannan) which is prepared from tubers of theAmorphophallus plant. Konjac is a normal Japanese foodstuff whichis made of crude glucomannan and water. Glucomannan (3.9 g) wasadministered to normal or diabetic subjects with 50 g of glucoseor test meal to observe the changes of the post-prandial rise inblood glucose, plasma insulin and plasma bile acids. Thedecreased effect of glucomannan on the post-prandial rise ofblood glucose and insulin levels was more pronounced when it wasadded to the test meal than when added to the glucose solution.When diabetic patients supplemented ward diets with 7.8 g or 11.7g glucomannan daily, their mean of cholesterol and fasting bloodglucose fell significantly and insulin dosage were reduced insome patients. The endogenous bile acid load test by egg yolkshowed that gelled glucomannan absorbed bile acids in the smallintestine, and subsequently reduced in the elevation of serumbile acids after the load. Whether carbohydrate was likely tohave been malabsorbed, 25 g xylose load test was conducted.Addition of fiber to the test glucose solution reduced the 2-hoururinary excretion of xylose in all cases, however when collectionof the 2-hour urinary aliquots was continued over a 6-hourperiod, total amount of xylose excretion in urine was the samefor both glucomannan and control. Effect of Dietary Fiber (Guar Gum and Konnyaku Powder) on Diabetic Control K. Shima, M. Tabata, A. Tanaka and Y. Shimomura The Department of Geriatrics and Medicine Osaka University School of Medicine Osaka, 553 Japan ABSTRACT The study was undertaken to investigate whether dietary fiberis also effective in our diabetics whose dietary habits appear tobe different from those of Westerners. The effects of guar gumand konnyaku powder consisting mainly of galactomannan andglucomannan, respectively, on plasma glucose, IRI, glucagonimmunoreactivity (GI) and glucagon-like immunoreactivity (GLI)were investigated in normals and diabetics. Konnyaku powdertended to flatten the glucose tolerance curve more remarkablycompared to guar gum in diabetics. Changes in plasma IRI levelswere parallel to those in plasma glucose. There was no differencein patterns of plasma GI and GLI response between OGTT and OGTTwith dietary fiber. Five diabetics, 4 obese MOD and one IDDM,were given 18 g guar gum over a 4-week period while taking theirhome diet. All patients but one IDDM showed a body weight loss of1 to 3 kg during the period and their mean urinary glucoseexcretion fell by 80%. The long term effectiveness and adverse effects of the agentswere followed for more than one year in these and four newlyselected patients. The agent was similarily effective over thelong term period in all but two whose disease became refractoryto the regimen after several months but well controlled again byits readministration following discontinuation for a few weeks. One of them experienced the same episode twice. No remarkableadverse effects were seen during the long term period. Allpatients experienced alleviation of exaggerated postprandialhunger sensation while taking the agent. The dietary fiber isconsidered to represent a useful adjunct in the dietary therapyof diabetics, particularly in obese maturity-onset diabetics alsoin our country. INTRODUCTION Obesity, along with increased levels of blood lipids, has longbeen a problem for many. There is no doubt that obesity, alongwith smoking, lack of exercise, and poor dietary habits stronglycontributes to the increasing amount of cardiovascular diseaseand likewise to the amount of deaths related to cardiovasculardisease. Any safe substance with the capacity of lowering theserum lipids and additionally resulting in dramatic weight losswould, logically, be worthwhile to test clinically. The L-112 Biopolymer has been refined in laboratories from thefiber of crustaceans. The L-112 Biopolymer-Fat Blocker is a formof this indigestible fiber. It has been proven to have strong fatbinding properties. Previous clinical trials showed excellentresults in reducing the level of cholesterol and triglycerides inblood, while the HDL fraction of cholesterol increased. The focus of the study of the L-112 Biopolymer was to measurethe weight reducing effect of L-112 Biopolymer. Overweightpatients were asked to participate in a study where L-112Biopolymer - Fatblocker was compared to a placebo. The patientswere placed on a diet for 14 days. This diet was comprised of950-1000 Kcal per day and consisted of 40% fat, with a maximalcontent of saturated fatty acids, 40% carbohydrates and 20%protein. Fibers, however, were not included by the dietist. Thestudy was initially for 14 days, but was prolonged for those whowanted to continue. Weekly evaluations were made. During eachvisit, the patients were questioned as to whether they had stuckto their diet program, had taken the capsules as prescribed, andas to whether their had been any unexpected events since theirlast examination. Weight and blood pressure were also measured.During the study itself, patients ingested the L-112 capsulesshortly before the start of lunch and dinner (four 240mgcapsules). Those who tested the L-112 Biopolymer were all at least 15%overweight for their height. They were both male and female andranged in age from 25ÊtoÊ70. This Biopolyer was notadvised for women who were pregnant or nursing, nor for anyonewith a history of liver and/or renal insufficiency,gastrointestinal disturbances, those who abuse alcohol or and/ordrugs, those suffering a stroke within the previous 3 months orwho have had clinical symptoms suggesting impending stroke, andanyone with a history of allergy to sea food. Super Formula Program TM How To Order Guaranteed Risk Free Or Call Us To Order At: 1-800-724-7546 RESULTS All patients were monitored for weight, blood pressure andadverse effects at each visit. While both groups reduced theirbody weight, the L-112 group lost measurably more weight (Figure1). Also, both systolic and diastolic blood pressure decreasedsignificantly for the L-112 users. The values for the L-112 groupwere much lower after both 2 and 4 weeks (see Figures 2a and 2b). ADVERSE EFFECTS At each visit patients were asked about events occurring sincetheir last visit. Twelve (12) patients complained of constipationover the first 2-3 days. However, seven of these patients werenot using L-112, but were merely following the diet. Two patientscomplained of slight nausea, one of these also complainedinitially of coldness. Two patients in the L-112 group complainedof headaches, but one of these two had been suffering headachesfor many years prior to undergoing the study. Constipation for 2-3 days was thought to be related to thediet itself. Most of the adverse effects disappeared within a fewdays. Some of the L-112 users reported a change of consistency ofthe feces, and of softer and smoother feces than usual,facilitating defecation. DIET There were only a few admitted deviations from the prescribeddiet based upon interviews with those ingesting the L-112. Someparticipants of the study found it difficult to adhere to thediet when dining out or when invited to dinner. Theresearchers took additional measures to document the weight lossassociated with the consumption of L-112. The study showed that after just 2 weeks of treatment, almost100% better with L-112 than without. After 4 weeks L-112 is evenmore effective. The results are quite noteworthy. It is possiblethat with slightly higher doses of L-112, better results yetwould have been obtained. Naturally, with the minimal side effects of L-112 Biopolymer,the question also arises whether weight reduction can also beachieved with a minimum of diet and effort. For example, onlyavoiding excesses like alcohol, butter, cream, and heavy meals.Research suggests that L-112 could still be of help. Weight reduction over a short periods of time is usually notdifficult. The problem is maintaining this weight loss over time.Few people are able to change their eating and exercise habitspermanently. Another important finding was that excellent blood pressuredecreases occurred in the obese patients with hypertension, withthe decrease in diastolic BP especially notable. Those who hadnormal blood pressure maintained their blood pressure while usingL-112, while hypertensives reduced their pressure to normallevels. It is also interesting to note that more negative effects wereexperienced by dieters who did not use L-112. Users of the L-112preferred it to other methods of weight loss they had previouslytried, such as powder mixes. CONCLUSION Studies show the L-112 Biopolymer to be an effective aid inweight loss for those suffering from obesity. An additionalbeneficial effect was blood pressure reduction in obesehypertensives with the absence of notable side effects. Home Directory Info Links Email copyright 1996/1997---The Share Guide---share@shareguide.com---http://www.shareguide.comWT01-B10-120IA092-000984-B007-48http://www.shareguide.com:80/compart.html 208.201.227.63 19970110074720 text/html 18483HTTP/1.0 200 Document followsDate: Fri, 10 Jan 1997 07:47:21 GMTServer: NCSA/1.5.2Last-modified: Tue, 23 Jul 1996 00:27:51 GMTContent-type: text/htmlContent-length: 18299 Complementary Medicine Theme: Complementary Medicine Complementary Health Care by Merri Harris, D.C. Western (allopathic) medicine has been the mainstream form of health care in this country for over 100 years. The passage of time has diluted the history of its ascendancy to its position of social, political and economic power. It was not until a report in the New England Journal of Medicine, within the past 3 years, that people (and especially the medical establishment) realized that allopathic medicine does not have a mortgage on health care in this country. This report stated that the American people are spending more money on so-called alternative medicines, mostly out of pocket, than they are on conventional medicines. Is it a wonder that the political/economic machine of the pharmaceutical/allopathic world has stepped into the Washington arena to stall health care reform? Complementary health care (I use the term "health care" instead of medicine, because medicine has come to imply the giving, or intrusion of, another substance or act) is a very broad spectrum of interventions, aids, counselling and approaches. These are forms of assistance that truly "compliment" the skills, advantages and undeniable brilliance of the emergent, radical interventions of allopathic medicine. Nobody should give up the right to the amazing skills of the micro-surgeon, the emergency room physician or the unsurpassed ability of an MRI or Cat-scan to discover, for instance, the source of bleeding in the brain. However, allopathic medicine generally does a poor job of assisting people with the every day needs of managing their physical, emotional and spiritual expression. Complementary health care providers tend to connect to their patient/clients on different levels. To be effective, they need to have an emotional and spiritual connection or understanding to truly comprehend the underlying needs of the person seeking assistance. Because complementary care providers often do not have the skills or knowledge to intervene in the emergency care of an individual, they tend to behave in a "preventative" way when dealing with health issues. If a person is already in a crisis of some form, complementary health care providers try to get to the original cause or source of the problem, rather than dealing with the signs and symptoms of the condition. There are some advantages to not having access to radical procedures to remedy problems that have been previously unattended. Vigilance and attention become the major tools of work, instead of reaction and suppression. What is a complementary health care provider? A good complementary practitioner is capable of making sound health care decisions based on understanding and knowledge of all of the components of a person's make-up. There should be consideration of not only the physical, but also the intellectual, emotional and spiritual aspects. Practitioners should have knowledge of a wide range of health care opportunities that may be appropriate for an individual, as well as have access and communication with others in the health care arena. Complementary health care practitioners should still have accountability for their actions and advice to ensure you that the practitioner is up to date with their education and has some type of peer review mechanism to ensure the safety of the public and the consumer. The definition listed here is not an exclusive one, but rather is advice concerning the criteria suggested if you plan to see a complementary health care practitioner. The list of possible people that you may consult is almost endless in an effort to achieve personal wholeness and satisfaction of all facets of your entire self. Your ethnic, cultural, and spiritual belief background must be accommodated if you are to gain truly satisfactory health care. The popular "arrival" of complementary health care is an interesting phenomenon and signals a huge change in the psyche of the population. The ongoing survival of complementary health care systems will be dependent on the will of the individual to take responsibility for his/her own health and a continuing demand for preventive rather than reactive health care measures. Merri Harris, D.C. is a holistic chiropractor and director of Healing Arts, a multi-disciplinary and multi-practitioner health care center located in Sebastopol. The center provides chiropractic, acupuncture, medical family practice, classical homeopathy, psychological counseling including EMDR, biofeedback, massage therapy and exercise and rehab. facilities. > Electromagnetic Fields and Your Immune System by Michael R. Neuert, MA, BSME As compared to conventional medicine, with its expertise in the diagnosis and treatment of symptoms, the value of a more holistic approach may be the recognition and treatment of the underlying conditions that allow "dis-ease" to exist. This article deals with one of the most controversial, yet perhaps most prevalent dis-ease conditions today: the bio-effects of electromagnetic fields (EMFs). EMFs are a type of low-frequency radiation emitted from everything electrical around us: power lines, transformers, electrical wiring, computers, TVs, lights, clocks, appliances, etc. Recent studies have linked EMFs to increased leukemia, lymphoma, brain cancer, melanoma, breast cancer, miscarriage, birth defects, suicide, and most recently, Alzheimer's disease. This wide range of health problems may be due to EMFs' effects on the pineal gland, which is the master gland of the body, secreting hormones which control our circadian rhythms, and regulate important functions of the brain and all the other glands. Researchers have discovered that EMFs can suppress the pineal glands' secretion of melatonin, a hormone which controls our wake/sleep cycle, moods and task performance. Depressed melatonin levels are associated with mood changes, depression and psychiatric disorders. Melatonin also plays a critical cancer role, by increasing the phytotoxicity of the body's natural killer lymphocytes. Suppression of pineal gland function has been implicated in the etiology of breast, ovarian, prostate and melanoma cancers. Other studies have linked EMFs to decreased production of enzymes called "protein kinases" in human lymphocyte cells. This also indicates that EMFs can suppress the immune system. Now, if EMFs can suppress the immune system to the point where cancer rates double or triple, what other effects might a suppressed immune system have on our day-to-day health and well being? Do we experience more colds, more allergies, and more susceptibility to other seemingly unrelated medical problems? Are we less capable of handling chemical pollution from the environment? And today, considering the prevalence of immune related disorders---from allergies to AIDS---wouldn't it be wise to support (rather than suppress) the immune system? A natural, holistic approach to health would suggest reducing EMFs as much as reasonably possible. Researchers have raised important concerns about both the electric and the magnetic components of EMF emissions. However, the greater concern is focused on the magnetic part, because repeated studies have linked magnetic field levels to increased childhood cancer deaths. Most magnetic field exposures come from power lines and electrical wiring. Other common sources are waterbeds, electric blankets, computers, fluorescent lights, TVs, telephones, appliances and automobiles. To detect magnetic fields, you can buy or rent a gaussmeter, or have a professional perform an inspection. Reductions can be as simple as avoiding high exposure locations. Electrical wiring can be repaired to installed according to low-EMF methods. Specific sources can be shielded. Low emission computers, telephones and appliances are becoming available. Anecdotal evidence indicated that AC (alternating current) electric fields are often involved when people are knowingly "sensitive" to electricity. Often referred to as "wired and tired," they may experience conditions ranging from a rather vague discomfort or irritation. to headaches, fatigue and other symptoms. In my observation, almost everyone today experiences an underlying level of "wired and tired" due to electric fields. Some individuals handle it better, perhaps having a stronger resistance to life's stresses. Others are more sensitive, and in extreme cases may experience allergies, depression, environmental illness, or chronic fatigue syndrome. If you are the type of person who feels better when the electricity suddenly goes off during a power failure, or when walking out in the woods away from any electricity, you may be sensitive to electric fields. Most electric field exposures come from building wiring. The remainder come from cords, appliances and nearby power lines. Electric fields are easy to reduce. Walls and ceilings can be painted with special shielded paint. New electrical wiring can be installed using shielded materials. In many homes, certain electrical circuits can be switched off at night, reducing the fields during sleep. Michael R. Neuert has over 10 years experience with the EMF issue. He is the owner of Safe Home & Office Company, providing complete EMF reduction services and products for Northern California. Alternatives for Breast Cancer Treatment by Tara Treasurfield In February of 1994, I had a mammogram. I was surprised when the radiology department of my HMO flew into a panic. Hysterical hospital personnel left "URGENT!" messages for me at work. The calls terrified me, and I knew that if I did have cancer, fear could only make matters worse. The calls also enraged me, as they violated my privacy, so I fired my HMO. Under a new HMO, I selected a holistically-oriented physician. When the lump on my breast had grown alarmingly two months after the mammogram, he recommended a lump biopsy. It disturbed me that he offered no alternative. But he had all the right credentials and said that the procedure was simple and virtually painless, so I decided to trust his judgment. We selected a surgeon and I made an appointment. Things did not go well. Six hours after the surgery, I was in tremendous pain. The incision had filled with blood, causing a hematoma. A few days after the biopsy, the surgeon told me over the telephone that the biopsy revealed the presence of cancer. He recommended more surgery, radiation and chemotherapy. He also told me that there was no way to relieve the pain from the hematoma, and guessed correctly that it would last for several months. He was actually surprised that all this bad news upset me, so I fired him. My physician tentatively recommended more surgery, combined with radiation. This time, I decided not to follow his advice. I felt as though my nightmares, of which there were many, had overflowed into waking life. My holistic physician, two surgeons, an acupuncturist and herbalist, my friends, casual acquaintances, and my family were unanimous in the opinion that surgery, radiation and chemotherapy were my only options. At one point, I seriously considered a mastectomy. Then in a dream, I saw the dark figure of a human form with little bits and pieces of its flesh lopped away. Awakening from this dream, I realized that if cutting, burning or poisoning my body were the only ways to deal with my predicament, then life just may not be worth living. I was shocked to discover that death was beginning to look appealing, and this discovery woke me up. Convinced that there must me another way, I arranged to visit a friend of 30 years who now lives in Ukiah, California. After a few hours with her, I felt like ME again, instead of a cancerous breast. She inspired me to hope, laugh, and choose to live. She reminded me that there really are alternative to conventional western medicine. Soon after that, I told a new friend about my condition and she invited me to a meeting of the Gerson network. There are people follow the Gerson therapy that were diagnosed as "terminal" as much as 30 years ago. Other approaches work, too. One of my business contacts in Napa, California was diagnosed with lung cancer and given 6 months to live. He quit his job, and spent what he thought were to be the last 6 months of his life helping his wife open an antique store. A year later, he was still alive, got a job, and became deeply involved in his work. That was 14 years ago! After hearing the stories of these wonderful people and realizing that my life may not be over after all, I shared my excitement with my physician. He responded that none of the options I was so excited about really works, so I fired him. Two months later, I dropped my insurance, both because I could no longer afford it, and because it was of no further use to me. Currently, I am treating my condition with a modified Gerson therapy, combined with herbal supplements and mental training. 1) Deal with the Basics Don't take the chance of adding more chemicals and toxins to your body. Eat only organic foods. If you eat flesh and/or dairy products, make sure they are free of antibiotics and growth hormones. Drink only filtered or distilled water. Store food and water in glass, not plastic. Use only non-toxic household cleansers and pest control products, and cosmetics that are free of chemicals. You can do this, with the help of your local natural foods market. 2) Be Honest, Be Selfish For every relationship, encounter, TV or radio program, piece of music, situation, thought, and feeling, pose the question, "Is this contributing to my healing?" If the answer is no, let it go. 3) Transform Fear and Think Positive Max Gerson wrote, "More people die of fear than of cancer." Dr. Bernie Siegel also speaks often and eloquently of the devastating effects of fear. When fears assail you, use whatever method you can to move quickly to a place of peace and confidence. Turn to friends or family for comfort. Trust that God, or Goddess, or the Higher Power, has everything under control. Read, read, read, and listen to inspirational audiotapes. Anything by Louise Hay, Dr. Bernie Siegel and Norman Vincent Peale, and Teach Only Love, by Gerald Jampolsky and Wellness Workbook by Travis and Ryan. Be aware of your dreams as well. Dream imagery reflects our deepest beliefs, and we tend to get what we deeply believe. If you have negative dream imagery, take the time to change it through writing, artwork or visualization. 4) Establish a Support System Comparing notes with those who face similar challenges can help you avoid their mistakes and reassure you when your "alarming symptoms" are actually a healing response. The more honest and open you are with friends and family members, the more they will be able to help you. I knew that I had good friends, but until I shared this challenge with them, I had no idea how good they really were. Someone wrote, "We are all dying. It's just that some of us are dying faster than others." I don't know if the treatment program I am following will allow me to live longer or cause me to die sooner. Of course I want to live, but for me, that is not the most important point. That's hard for many of the people who care about me to understand. But more than anything else, I want to deepen my trust in process---the kind of trust that's reflected in a line from Desiderata: �"�and whether or not it is clear to you, no doubt the universe is unfolding as it should." I am only one cell in the body of Gaia, and I don't know how I figure in the overall plan. I do know that the dis-ease in my body has volumes to teach me about believing in myself, claiming my power and authority, looking terror squarely in the face, and relating fully to other people. That doesn't mean that I want to keep this dis-ease around. I intend to get rid of it, by listening closely to what it's telling me about my life--and changing. If I can pull that off, whether I live to be only 51, or reach 85 or 90, won't matter so much. At least I will have lived. Tara Treasurefield is a dream consultant and writer in Glen Ellen, California.
