They can be sent to: Editor, M&AE Newsletter 105 Upson Hall Cornell University Ithaca, New York 14853-7501 or by e-mail to: maenews@mae.cornell.eduWT01-B10-146IA053-000898-B007-75http://maemac.mae.cornell.edu:80/M%26AE%20News4/director.html 128.84.141.69 19970111233036 text/html 4481HTTP/1.0 200 OKMIME-Version: 1.0Server: WebSTAR/1.0 ID/6725Message-ID: Date: Saturday, 11-Jan-97 22:30:30 GMTLast-Modified: Wednesday, 17-Apr-96 14:36:13 GMTContent-type: text/htmlContent-length: 4224 Director's Desk From the Director's Desk Professor David Caughey Director of M&AE As I write these words, I have just finished the Sibley School AnnualReport for my second year as Director. It has been an exciting and productiveyear, and I would like to share with you some impressions. Perhaps the moststriking statistic of the School is the continued growth in undergraduateenrollments and degrees awarded. The figure below shows the history of bachelorof science degrees in mechanical engineering awarded annually for each ofthe last twenty-one years - roughly my tenure at Cornell, having come asa visiting assistant professor in the fall of 1974. The growth is remarkable- a virtual doubling of ME graduates to a total of 173 this past year, duringa period when the total number of bachelors degrees awarded by the Collegeof Engineering at Cornell has remained almost constant. (The plot comparesthe number of mechanical engineering graduates each year with 1/8 of thetotal number of graduates in engineering, since the Sibley School facultyconstitutes approximately 1/8 of the total college faculty; thus the plotalso informs us that the 'productivity' of the Sibley School faculty - atleast in terms of undergraduate engineering degrees - has grown to morethan twice the average for the college.) What are the forces driving this continued interest in mechanicalengineering? I have no quantitative data on which to base an answer to thisquestion, but there are several, rather obvious, factors that may be responsible.First, the trend is consistent with those at other engineering collegesthroughout the country, so there must be national forces at work. I believethese include the 'durability' of a mechanical engineering degree based,at least in part, on the breadth of a mechanical engineering education andthe recognition of the importance of manufacturing to the health of thenational economy. And, of course, manufacturing is an inherently mechanicalengineering activity. Second, I believe the trend also is influenced byfactors local to Cornell. As can be seen from a number of items in this,and other, editions of Sibley School Newsletters, there is a great dealof project activity in the School. These projects provide students withhands-on experience in design and the construction of engineering prototypes,help to develop communication skills and encourage teamwork, and motivatethe students to further study in a variety of technical areas. In addition,the enthusiasm of the students for this project activity is an extremelyeffective advertisement for mechanical engineering as seen by freshmen andsophomores. The quality of the faculty and the curriculum also must be factors, butmy perception is that these are uniformly excellent across the engineeringfields at Cornell, so cannot be responsible for large differences in growthrates between the various undergraduate programs. We were pleased to seethat, in this spring's U. S. News and World Report rankings of graduateprograms in engineering, Cornell's ranking improved to sixth in the nationamong research-intensive universities. Also, we were very pleased with theresults of a review of the Sibley School by an External Review Committeethis past February. The review committee, consisting of distinguished academicsand engineers from industry, and chaired by Dr. Richard Aubrecht ('66, MS'68, Ph.D. '70), Chairman of the Board of Moog, Inc., found the School andits programs to be of substantially higher quality than had been perceivedby most of the committee members before their visit. They concluded theirreport to Dean John Hopcroft with the words, "This is a very good department.Don't mess with it too much!" But a more complete discussion of thatreview, including our plans for the future, will have to wait for the nextissue! Composting Facility Opens in Dakota County 1st in TwinCities — Source Separated Organics Composting SKB Environmental hasopened the first Twin Cities facility for composting sourceseparated organics such as food processing waste and soiledpaper. The site began accepting yard wastes in October 1996, andwill begin processing other source separated organics fromcommercial, industrial, and institutional sources early in 1997. Source separated compostable materials,blended with yard waste, will be composted using aeratedcontainment technology. These systems function much likein-vessel composting systems, but in a much less costly andcomplex manner. Through a twelve to sixteen week activedecomposition period, forced aeration maintains aerobicconditions within the containers and controls odor generation.Containers remain undisturbed throughout this active compostingcycle. Control of feedstocks, moisture, and oxygen consistentlyproduces high quality Class I compost — a high demandproduct for agricultural use, landscapers, contractors, publicworks developments, and other users. The new facility for source separatedcompostable materials is located on 37 acres within DakotaCounty's Resource Recovery Center in Empire Township. It is anoutgrowth of a preliminary pilot demonstration which wasconducted at SKB Environmental's Malcolm Streetfacility in Minneapolis. That experience coupled with thecompany's investigations of containment technologies prompted thedecision to pursue a full-scale facility. The facility's maximumthroughput, as licensed by Dakota County, will be approximately78,000 tons/year (50% source separated compostable materials; 50%yard waste). Initially volumes processed will be lower, but areexpected to grow quickly as education and marketing of haulersand generators takes place. The types of waste to be processed aregenerally limited to the following: (if your browser doesn't support tables,select the textversion) MATERIALS ACCEPTABLE FOR COMPOSTING Type Specific Examples Food Processing Wastes Hulls, rejects, and by-products resulting from food processing activities Food Preparation/Service Wastes Plate scrapings, coffee grounds, egg shells, or other scrapings or peelings from food preparation or service Wet or Soiled Paper Soiled or wet fiber products, including cardboard, paper towels, paper food liners, coffee filters, fast-food wrappings, or other compostable but not readily recyclable materials Yard Waste Leaves, grass clippings, brush, or wood wastes from commercial or residential sources Unrecyclable Paper Fiber materials separated by the generator for recycling but subsequently rejected or determined by the recycler to be unrecyclable. Garden Wastes Plants, Floral waste, Trimmings, Overripe vegetables, and other compostable discards from gardening and horticultural activities, or from florists or garden markets Construction & Demolition Transfer Station and RecyclingFacility In the heart of the TwinCities—Minneapolis and St. Paul, SKB Environmentalis developing a transfer facility for construction/demolitionwaste at 620 Malcolm Street SE. The facility will process C&Dwastes and recover corrugated cardboard, brick, wood, ferrous andnon-ferrous metals, and other economically recoverable materials. Rick O'Gara, SKB Environmental'sPresident: "Development of this kind of facility has been apriority for us. For C&D contractors and haulers in the urbanarea, we will represent a cost-effective alternative to haulingmaterials to remote landfills. Our location near Highway 280means there will be significant savings in travel costs andturnaround time for haulers using our facility — animportant factor in this industry." John Domke, SKB Environmental'sVice President: "Our schedule is to have this facility inoperation by mid-1997. It will be able to handle up to 1,400cubic yards per day. We will recycle materials for which thereare economical markets and will transfer the balance of C&Dwastes to licensed disposal facilities. A wholly owned subsidiary of CarlBolander & Sons Company, Minnesota's premier specialists insite preparation and demolition, SKB Environmental wasformed in 1983, as one of the first privately held demolitionwaste disposal companies to serve the construction industry inMinnesota. In those early years, the company functioned as acomplement to Bolander's demolition business, arrangingcost-effective disposal services for construction and demolition(C&D) debris. In 1989, we opened Minnesota's firststate-of-the-art landfill for disposal of C&D waste. Typicalof the company's commitment to responsible practices, the RichValley Landfill is the first clay lined C&D landfill withleachate collection in Minnesota. In fact, it is one of a handfulof C&D facilities in the nation that combine such rigorousdesign features with stringent operating practices andgroundwater monitoring — becoming a model facility for theC&D industry. Environmental data from the Rich Valleyfacility was relied upon heavily in EPA's recent development ofRCRA standards for disposal of C&D materials. Informationabout potential impacts from C&D facilities is available in awhite paper and background studies prepared for the NationalAssociation of Demolition Contractors. Our commitment to environmentalprotection is also reflected in SKB Environmental's focuson recycling economically recoverable concrete,brick, block,ferrous and non-ferrous metals, corrugated cardboard and woodwaste in its operations. The first large-scale state-of-the-artC&D processing facility/transfer station in Minnesota's TwinCities Area is being developed at our facility in centralMinneapolis. Expanding our services to include yardwaste management — composting of leaves and grass andproduction of landscape mulch from brush and wood wastes, we havebecome the largest yard waste processor in Minnesota, currentlyoperating four facilities, with total processed quantitiesexceeding 60,000 tons in 1995. At the company's Empire Township site,another Minnesota "first" has opened —Minnesota's first composting facility for source separatedcompostable materials. The facility will blend wastes like foodprocessing residues with yard waste and compost the materialsusing innovative containment technology. SKB Environmental has anexcellent reputation:     for doing the correct thing environmentally;     for customer satisfaction, service, and value;     for the rapport and high regard the company has earned with regulatory and permitting agencies;     and for its performance record of never receiving a citation or notice of violation for any of its operations. Maintaining that record isour top priority because it directly translates to peaceof mind for our customers. Our commitment to environmentallyresponsible recycling, waste transfer and land disposal meets theneeds of the demolition, construction and remodeling industriesfor services and facilities compliant with today's andtomorrow's regulatory environment. For land disposal of C&D wastes, SKBEnvironmental's policies require state-of-the-artengineering, construction, monitoring, and operating practices.On-site supervisors at all SKB Environmentalsites are state certified C&D landfill operators. Our new Minneapolisfacility will enable us toincrease the C&D recycling opportunities available at ourRich Valley Landfill and Recycling Center.Each of these facilities exemplifies SKB Environmental'smanagement philosophy. If you're concerned about C&Dmanagement, recycling, or regulatory compliance, please contactus. Demolition Landfilling Minnesota's state-of-the-art landfill fordemolition and construction debris is SKB Environmental's RichValley Demolition Disposal Facility. Opened in 1989, the facilityis designed with a clay liner and leachate collection system toprotect the environment now and in the future, providingenvironmental safeguards that ensure peace-of-mind for wastegenerators. SKB Environmentalprocesses demolition and construction debris yearly from largeand small projects. Material deposited in the landfill isvisually inspected to ensure environmental integrity, and acomputerized data system tracks the origin of all debris. At ourlandfill facility, C & D waste is first sorted forrecyclables, and then the waste to be disposed of is placed andcompacted to proper density. The landfill is manned and equippedto provide acceptable turnaround times which translates to costsavings for the customer.   State-of-the-ArtConstruction:     Two-foot thick clay liner        Leachate collection system         Upgradient and Downgradient ground water monitoring network     The schematic belowillustrates the design for the liner and leachate collectionsystem installed at the Rich Valley Landfill. At the landfillbase, the compacted clay liner has a minimum thickness of twofeet and meets a permeability specification of 1 x 10-7 cm/sec. The leachate collection systemis constructed of six inch PVC collection pipes (Schedule 80).Above the liner and leachate collection pipes there is a threefoot thick protective cushion/drainge layer, whichconsists ofnative sandy soils with minimum permeability of 5 x 10-3 cm/sec. The clay liner interceptsleachate as it percolates from the base of the waste deposit anddrainage layer. The upper surface of the clay liner is sloped sothat leachate flows by gravity to the collection pipes and thento a lift station. The lift station is a central collection pointfrom which leachate is pumped to tanker trucks for discharge to alocal wastewater treatment facility. Because of the comparativelyuncontaminated nature of the leachate, SKB environmental is notassessed a strength charge for leachate disposal. There are sixmonitoring wells, screened in the unconsolidated glacial driftaquifer underlying the facility, which are used to monitorupgradient and downgradient ground water quality.                                            Transfer        Station & Recycling Center         The Rich        Valley Landfill Recycling Center accepts "white        goods" and demolition and construction debris from a        variety of sources, including businesses and homeowners        through a transfer station. The station transfers        construction waste to environmentally sound and cost        effective disposal at the Rich Valley Landfill. Wood        products, car tires, and white goods such as        refrigerators, stoves, hot water heaters and washing        machines are recycled.         An innovative program to recycle        shingle waste into asphalt roadbase is also conducted at        the Recycling Center. SKB Environmental        is working with a large-scale shingle manufacturer,        Dakota County, and the State of Minnesota to evaluate        optimal amounts of this waste material that can be used        in state-certified roadbase mixes.                         Copyright © 1996SKB Environmental This site last modified: December 11, 1996 Developed by JohnH at LBA, Inc. Many states, including Minnesota where SKBEnvironmental's corporate offices are located, havebanned it from landfills and from solid waste processingfacilities such as incinerators. Even if allowed under statelegislation and local ordinances, disposing of yard waste withother household trash may not make economic sense. SKBEnvironmental can turn a disposal problem into anenvironmentally beneficial product for soil enhancement orlandscaping. At its own sites or on a contract basis, SKBEnvironmental will provide services tailored for the needs ofyour community. Services offered include: on-site staffing;mechanized debagging; aerated static pile composting; productscreening, bagging and marketing; and brush and wood chipping,with either mobile or on-site grinders. We are proud of ourrecord in providing cost-effective, reliable and problem-freeYard Waste Processing services. For further information about SKBEnvironmental's services please contact us.  Sites and Locations SKB Environmental isnow Minnesota's largest Yard Waste processing company. Annually,approximately 40,000 tons of leaves, grass clippings andbrush are composted and 20,000 tons of wood waste andbrush are processed into landscaping mulch. At each of our composting sites, leavesand grass are processed into compost using the aerated staticpile method. Finished compost is screened and marketed for salein bulk or in bags. Landscape mulch is produced from brush and/orwood wastes. EmpireTownship SKB Environmental hasopened a composting site on 37 acres within Dakota County'sresource recovery project site in Empire Township. This facilityaccommodates two types of composting, yard waste only andblending of yard waste with other source separated compostablematerials such as food or gardening wastes which are thencomposted using innovative containment technologies. Containmentsystems control odors and nuisance impacts while saving space. Auniform, high quality compost is produced for landscapers andother users. Using static aerated pile composting and SKBEnvironmental's unique yard waste de-bagging system, theyard waste compost produced is reliably of a quality that isbagged as potting soil, compost, topsoil, and other soilamendments sold for unrestricted retail distribution. Under thefacility's license from Dakota County, it has the capacity toprocess approximately 78,000 tons annually. Lakeville Site SKB Environmental operates theLakeville Yard Waste Compost Facility on 10 acres within a 21acre site located south of Co. Rd. 42 on Pilot Knob Road in AppleValley, MN. The facility is open to the public, serving theresidents of Lakeville, Apple Valley, Farmington, Rosemount, andsurrounding communities in this rapidly growing part of theMetropolitan Area. CottageGrove Site The City of Cottage Grove's CompostFacility at Highway 61 & Jamaica Avenue is operated on acontract basis. The facility serves city residents and householdsfrom nearby Hastings and from communities north of Cottage Grove. SKBEnvironmental utilizes approximately 3 of the site's 20acres. City ofMinneapolis SKB Environmentalmanages all yard waste for the City of Minneapolis, MN (1990population 368,363) at this 17 acre site located at 620 MalcolmAvenue SE. Yard waste delivered to the site is now transferred toanother of SKB Environmental's sites forcomposting.         Copyright © 1996SKB Environmental This site last modified: December 10, 1996 Developed by JohnH at LBA, Inc. Current research includes identification of baselinesoil characteristics and testing of compost applications todetermine whether it is possible to obtain an NPK(nitrogen/phosphorous/potassium) benefit comparable toapplication of commercial fertilizers. Research entails analysisof release rates throughout the growing cycle and tracking cropyields, testing after crops are removed to check residualnutrients as well as their availability and mobility compared tocommercial fertilizers. Testing is conducted at different soildepths to also measure nutrient migration. Analysis also measureschanges in soil characteristics such as moisture holding capacityresulting from compost or yard waste applications. Rick O'Gara, President of SKBEnvironmental: "We are happy to share informationabout our program with persons who have an interest in compostingand agricultural end uses. Waste professionals, agriculturalresearchers, and the public are welcome to schedule a tour of thefacility. As research results become available, they'll be madeavailable in our What's New section." Landfill Operator Training When the Minnesota Pollution ControlAgency developed a separate certification program forconstruction/demolition landfill operators five years ago, theMPCA turned to SKB Environmental for helpteaching the course. Six times each year, our staff providetraining in facility operations, management, equipment andmaintenance, and regulatory reporting. "Making our knowledgeand experience available to improve our industry is what SKBEnvironmental is all about," John Domke, VicePresident for Operations.      Other Resources We've found some enlighteninginformation on productive reuse, waste minimization, andpollution prevention at the locations listed. Because of the comparativelyuncontaminated nature of the leachate, SKB environmental is notassessed a strength charge for leachate disposal. There are sixmonitoring wells, screened in the unconsolidated glacial driftaquifer underlying the facility, which are used to monitorupgradient and downgradient ground water quality.                                            Transfer        Station & Recycling Center         The Rich        Valley Landfill Recycling Center accepts "white        goods" and demolition and construction debris from a        variety of sources, including businesses and homeowners        through a transfer station. The station transfers        construction waste to environmentally sound and cost        effective disposal at the Rich Valley Landfill. Wood        products, car tires, and white goods such as        refrigerators, stoves, hot water heaters and washing        machines are recycled.         An innovative program to recycle        shingle waste into asphalt roadbase is also conducted at        the Recycling Center. SKB Environmental        is working with a large-scale shingle manufacturer,        Dakota County, and the State of Minnesota to evaluate        optimal amounts of this waste material that can be used        in state-certified roadbase mixes.                         Copyright © 1996SKB Environmental This site last modified: December 11, 1996 Developed by JohnH at LBA, Inc. Current research includes identification of baselinesoil characteristics and testing of compost applications todetermine whether it is possible to obtain an NPK(nitrogen/phosphorous/potassium) benefit comparable toapplication of commercial fertilizers. Research entails analysisof release rates throughout the growing cycle and tracking cropyields, testing after crops are removed to check residualnutrients as well as their availability and mobility compared tocommercial fertilizers. Testing is conducted at different soildepths to also measure nutrient migration. Analysis also measureschanges in soil characteristics such as moisture holding capacityresulting from compost or yard waste applications. Rick O'Gara, President of SKBEnvironmental: "We are happy to share informationabout our program with persons who have an interest in compostingand agricultural end uses. Waste professionals, agriculturalresearchers, and the public are welcome to schedule a tour of thefacility. As research results become available, they'll be madeavailable in our What's New section." Landfill Operator Training When the Minnesota Pollution ControlAgency developed a separate certification program forconstruction/demolition landfill operators five years ago, theMPCA turned to SKB Environmental for helpteaching the course. Six times each year, our staff providetraining in facility operations, management, equipment andmaintenance, and regulatory reporting. "Making our knowledgeand experience available to improve our industry is what SKBEnvironmental is all about," John Domke, VicePresident for Operations.      Other Resources We've found some enlighteninginformation on productive reuse, waste minimization, andpollution prevention at the locations listed. Guaranteed Acceptance Our aim is to smooth the way for you from the start. So we guarantee you will be accepted as a Prime Health customer if you are under the age of 75 and resident in the UK. Any such pre-existing medical condition may become eligible for cover. Provided that you remain free of any treatment, advice, medication or check-ups for that condition or any related condition for a continuous period of two years following the start of the policy. Is There Anything We Don't Cover? Like all other insurers, there are certain things Primecare will not cover. For example: chronic long-term illness, wilful self-inflicted injuries, AIDS, normal pregnancy, cosmetic treatment, regular renal dialysis, routine examinations and GP and dental visits.
